Helldivers 2 used to be one of the most fun and chaotic co-op games I’ve ever played. Jumping in with friends, experimenting with loadouts, and laughing through the chaos was pure gold. But over time, update after update, that fun has slowly been stripped away.The game has had its ups and downs, but lately it’s been nothing but downhill. The fun keeps getting nerfed, the pain keeps getting buffed. What used to be a sandbox for creativity has become a rigid meta where only a handful of guns and armours are worth using.The Warbond system could’ve been great, but now it’s just a cosmetic treadmill. Every new “content drop” brings more bugs, more broken objectives, and more frustration. Silent enemies, clipping through walls, unkillable mobs, game crashes — they’ve all become a regular part of the experience. New enemies feel rushed and badly balanced, with no real counterplay or logic behind their design. With so much variety in weapons, stratagems, and armour, you’d think there’d be a coherent system tying it all together… but there just isn’t anymore. What’s worse is that there was a time when it felt like the devs listened, like they cared about making the game better but not anymore. At this point, it’s sad to see how far this game has fallen. I really loved Helldivers 2 and wanted it to succeed, but I can’t recommend it in its current state. If you’re looking for the game that once brought so many players together in chaotic, hilarious freedom — it’s gone.

A love letter to the most patriotic co-op chaos ever made — where freedom has never been so loud, or so fun!

Wow, where to start?

Are you a fan of D&D and roleplay?

Have you been looking for a game to grind out with friends and laugh while doing it?

Do you want to prove you’ve got what it takes to sweat like the sweatiest of try-hards?

Have you been searching for a community that welcomes cadets (newbies) with open arms?

Well, look no further, my new brothers and sisters — your new home awaits right here on Super Earth!

This is where legends are forged in the fires of our galactic war!
Where courage and conviction elevate you beyond mere citizenry — to Super Citizen!

Let Lady Liberty guide your hands, new recruit, and trust that those who’ve fought since release to bring you this masterclass in gaming — Helldivers 2 — will continue to stand by your side for a greater galaxy! Where the white, yellow, and blue banners of Managed Democracy fly high across every last star!

If you haven’t already gathered by now: I absolutely LOVE THIS GAME.

It isn’t without faults, sure — but let’s be honest with ourselves, what game isn’t? What game is impervious to nitpicking or critique?

I want to be absolutely fair and brutally honest with anyone on the fence: this game has broken before, and it will break again. I can almost guarantee it. The devs at Arrowhead couldn’t have possibly anticipated the amount of hype this game has generated. Practically overnight, it’s become a pop culture phenomenon — and with that comes the strain of massive player surges, server issues, and the challenge of maintaining a game built on a completely dead engine that’s currently being held together with Super Earth justice glue and Freedom-tape!

But despite all that, the real ones — those who see the heart of this game — have stuck by it through thick and thin. I’m proud to count myself among those who’ve been here since Day One.

Don’t let my Steam hours fool you — I started on PlayStation, maxed out my character, fought in every war, and bought it again on PC just to relive the experience from a newcomer’s perspective. Because let’s be real: once you’ve unlocked everything as a day-one player, there’s not much new content until the next Warbond drops. But even so — what a time to join the game!

Right now, new players are welcomed by 17 Warbonds packed with pages of gear, weapons, stratagems, emotes — the works. You’re stepping into a fully fleshed-out universe, rich with history shaped entirely by the community’s collective actions in the galactic war. There are three factions of enemies, each with subtypes and unique strategies to discover, weaknesses to exploit, and plenty of ways to spread that sweet, sweet LIBER-TEA!

And for my fellow hardcore roleplayers — this game even has a War Map that, once you learn how to read it, opens a whole new level of immersion. I’m not just talking about planning your next mission — I’m talking about joining fleets on Discord, analyzing Joel’s plans, deciding which anchor planets to defend to protect vital supply lines, and coordinating where to deploy democracy space stations like a true commander.

Did I mention I love this game?

Helldivers 2 has genuinely become a part of my life in an incredible way, and I want others to experience that too. It’s rare for a studio to make a game with this much passion, detail, and love for their community.

I want this game to succeed not just because I’m a hardcore fan, but because studios like Arrowhead deserve to set the standard for the industry. We need to stop rewarding the big, soulless corporations that shovel out copy-paste slop filled with microtransactions and “live service” nonsense. Stop paying for $20 skins after a $70–$100 entry fee — and start supporting studios that give you a full experience out of the gate.

If you need a simple reason to pull the trigger, here it is:

HELLDIVERS 2 is $40 — and you can unlock everything for free, just by playing the game.

If this were E3 1995, that right there would be the PS2 price-tag mic drop moment.

So what are you doing right now, citizen?
Buy the game. Suit up.
Join me in some drops new recruit!

This game is a conflicting mess of great and awful. the game itself is fantastic and fun with a great community and lots of potential. However. the developers have seemed to turn to churning out update after update without ACTUAL playtesting or legitimate bug fixes. things said to have been tweaked in devlogs are either not changed at all or changed to NEGATIVELY impact the game. Getting tossed around over and over again with no chance to retaliate even Right AFTER dropping gets very tiring and over all just makes anyone not want to play anymore. Armor values seems to mean absolutely nothing as with heavy armor you move slower and have less stamina but still get two shot by common terminids like standard warriors as if you were wearing Light Armor instead. This is still a great game. but It feels more and more like the devs are just tossing shit at the wall and not even fixing what any of it breaks or even TESTING to see if their tweaks have actually changed anything before they lob it out in a "Bugfix" patch. Take your chances on it how you like, but ultimately I am very dissapointed and if things keep going this way, I dont imagine i'll be a dedicated diver much longer.

Don't listen to the complainers - this game is incredible.

Intense, gripping combat, a massive variety of cool weapons and equipment to play with, a grounded aesthetic, and epic moments.
Add in an ever-evolving story that players can rally around, excellent crossover content that maintains the game's identity, and the Arrowhead team's responsiveness and ongoing attention to the players' thoughts, and this is a game I could play for years.
I especially appreciate that I don't feel like I have to spend additional money to keep up with the meta or chase limited-time items like in other games. They keep the starting gear viable even once you've leveled up.
But the reason I keep coming back to Helldivers 2 is the challenge of each new mission and loadout combo, the epic moments that the game continually produces, and the memories I make playing with friends.

Let me preface this by saying that I have over 50 hours on steam along with over 200 on Playstation. I love this game a lot and the general gameplay loop, although kinda boring when you get the same MO over and over agiain, is still one of the most fun games ive played in a long time.
However, the game in its current state is almost unlplayable, if its not a crash every time theres more then 20 enemies, its getting crazy frame drops no matter what. When I first got this game I played it at ultra settings on an ARC B580, so not the best gpu but it got over 100 fps. Recently, though, ive barely gotten over 20 fps, and that didnt change when moving to medium or even low settings. The game has also grown exponentially since I bought it, as its now well over 100 gigs, and is moving very quickly to 150.
So, unfourtunately, I dont recommend Helldivers in its current state, no matter how much I want to.

This game is cinematic, and interesting, and unfortunately, more frustrating than anything else.  I've been playing since the beginning and I've reached a point where playing it for any length of time makes me quit mid-mission in disgust.  All practicing and mastering the game did was expose how often you get killed at random by terrible mechanics and game-breaking bugs.  The Developer has this delusion about whats fun in a game is being helpless and impotent.  They call it "grunt fantasy" and talk about the "science" of their balancing.  Balancing where the starter weapons are just as effective as anything you can spend hours earning access to.  Where invisible walls hold you down or ricochet your weapons back into your helpless corpse.  Where enemies don't even get weakpoints or have so much health you can't even bother fighting them, or pop out of the ground mid-attack you can only avoid with very specific loadouts.  There are so many weapons in the game that just dont really work or make sense and go completely unused because of the strict requirements these unreasonable "grunt fantasy" conditions force on you.  Balancing that makes a meta where only one of the hundreds of possible gear combinations might work. Recoilless rifle/Supply pack, thermite grenades, ultimatum.  Yawn.  It's really sad because this game looks awesome and wants to be played.  It wants to be popular.  It wants to not need an emergency balance patch every few months.  But the reality is, for every die hard fan who wants to debate this sort of complaint, there are 10 who just silently move on to a more fun game.  You can't debate this, you have to just make the game fun to play.  Grunt Fantasy is an oxymoron, I don't know who doesn't understand this at Errorhead but it is going to run your game into the ground.

Helldivers 2 was always a kooky, fun, grindy game that scratched that itch for squashing bugs, cracking robots, and (semi-recently) annihilating traditional aliens. Arrowhead has tried their darndest to throw us bones here and there for flavor, and it is difficult to maintain balance on such a large prospect of a game with 10 difficulties.

They fucked it.

It is now a seasonal, battle-pass-changes-everything game that no longer resembles what I originally encountered from launch into a year plus of playing. The reasons your character dies are no longer your own fault. It tirelessly punishes you for trying to do anything single-player. It immediately brutalizes you for trying to grind your face on the "Major Order". It's not fun. Roleplay has its limits. I'm not a teenager with 13+ hours to spend gettin' gud anymore. Your character isn't supposed to be an invincible super-hero, but they sure as fuck aren't supposed to be made of rice paper, and those delicious guns you spent days farming credits, samples, and upgrades over sure as shit shouldn't feel like confetti with a fully upgraded Helldiver and loadout.

Arrowhead, I've given well over $100 in super-credits because I indeed had FOMO, plus the supporter money from launch for a full-priced game. I've got my play-time out of this game, but then you made it end-of-life obsolete for me by making the same fucking game unplayable by the sheer mechanics you promised players so many times, so heartily you'd change.

I'm getting off this roller coaster, I thank you for the lolz, but I can no longer enjoy playing in a kids sand box if I scraped together 40 minutes out of my adult working life, or getting absolutely dick-punched if I touch the difficulty modifier up one or two ticks to "fully-unlock" the HD2 experience. You listened to the sweat lords too much and it's now a fucking professional sport instead of a GAME.

This is one of the greatest game's I've ever played, unfortunately it feels like every update makes it worse. Rupture Strain is back and it is genuinely just not fun. I feel like a hero dropping my exosuit and tearing apart the enemies during the last stretch of the mission, now just to have it be blown up 3 seconds later by a charger that burrowed underground and appeared 3 feet from my face; just one aspect of the disgusting difficulty increase that Rupture Strain adds, even on level 6 which I was playing on.

Gameguard anti-cheat has also been known as invasive and, from what I've heard, ineffective. If the only point is to deter less dedicated cheaters, something like EasyAnticheat would work just as well.

And, from what I've seen, the moderators at major lines of communication such as the Helldivers2 Discord and  r/Helldivers2 have been incredibly aggressive when it comes to silencing complaints; which, while in spirit of the lore of the game, is distasteful and frustrating.

I've been mostly ignoring all of this and continuing to play the game, but until Rupture Strain is either reworked again or removed entirely, I'm not sure it's even worth the 140GB it takes up.

This brings me to my final point; the game takes up 140GB of space, and takes unusually long to download to a HDD despite their claims of the size being for "HDD Optimization." This leaves you needing to dedicate 140GB of space to your SSD, assuming you have one.

In conclusion, this is still a great game and has the potential to be one of the best, but only if the developers prioritize giving the players a challenging but enjoyable experience.

I will change my review at such a time that they do, but for now they seem dead set on making the game progressively less fun to play, while slowing increasing the download size and destroying performance, all while Gameguard has total access to your computer.

I'm a fan. I've been playing since Helldivers 1. That's my bias - to me, this franchise is extremely fun. 
Helldivers 2 is a game, developed by people, played by people, published by companies. 

The game itself is so much fun. The publishers sometimes made dumb decisions to meet their own profit goals. Inconsequential because the game itself is so much fun. The developers are actively engaged with the game community and bring regular updates, fixes, etc. 

Experiment with all the different weapons, strategems, equipment, armor, etc. 
And then you find a combination that fits your unique playstyle. So much fun in the chaos. 
And then you encounter a mission or an enemy where that stuff doesn't work as well.
So then you adapt and try a new strategy. And hopefully that works. Learning is fun. 
There are a LOT of weapons/strategems/equipment to try out. I still haven't tried all of them.

If you keep dying on a higher difficulty, there's no shame in lowering the difficulty so you can calmly learn the strategies that work on the tougher enemies. When the "Into the Unjust" expansion released, I hated the Hive Lord and had no idea how to kill the Dragonroach. The Rupture Bugs are a fucking menace too. So I dropped the difficulty until I learned how to [kind of] deal with the new enemies.

One of the best parts of the game is the opportunity to have epic moments. They'll arise and you'll be clutch, or you won't. Your teammate can pull off some amazing feat and save your ass. Or, they won't. It's fun and chaotic and scary and fun and epic and funny. 

Bottom line, GREAT game. That's it.

I have over 800 hours in this game. I loved this game for quite a while, but with the changes that have been made recently, I just can't recommend it. I'll try my best to give it an honest review, though.

The Good:
1) Community: The community for this game is awesome. I've yet to see another community like Helldivers 2. Doesn't matter if you have friends in the game or not, you can always find a cool group of people to play with.
2) Unique Tactical Choices: At this point in the game, there are so many loadout options that you can get really creative with how you approach obstacles. It's fun make loadouts that work for everything. It's also fun to abandon what you're used to, make a totally wacky loadout, and then figure out how to make it work when you hit the ground. The mechanics are creative and fun (when they work).
3) Unique Missions: The game does a great job of making every mission feel singular. I have never played on the same map twice. I have solo'd level 6 missions. I have had my but kicked on a level 3 mission. (I'll come back to this point later, actually)
4) Fun in Groups: If you and your friends like extraction shooters, this game is almost always a good time as long as you don't take it too seriously.
5) Active Live Service: Arrow Head studios has (until recently: it sounds like they've taken a break from releasing new content to address some technical debt) been pretty consistent at adding new content to the game (I will also return to this point later). You can gain access to the new content by buying Super Credits, but you can also just get super credits by playing the game. Arrow Head has my respect for working against the greed of the industry and allowing players to access everything just by playing their game. Huge W for AH studios in my opinion. 

The Bad:
1) Continuing from point 3 above - Game Balance: There is literally no way to tell what is going to happen next in this game. In some ways, this is a cool characteristic of the game. In other ways, it's extremely frustrating. The balance of the game feels like it is constantly shifting. Sometimes it feels like the Devs don't even know what going on. I'm not talking about the story of the game, I'm talking about the gameplay and mechanics of the game. It feels unstable. One day a weapon works. The next day the Devs have nerfed it (sometimes without saying anything). One day an enemy type is a challenging obstacle. The next day you're avoiding planets entirely because that unit *might* be there.
2) Discontinued Game Engine: If you take anything away from this review, make sure it's this: AH studios built Helldivers 2 in game engine called Autodesk Stingray. This game engine has been discontinued since 2018. I don't think the engine has official support anymore, which means whenever something breaks AH Studios has to figure out how to fix it on their own. Game stability has consistently become worse and worse. This is a massive problem because...
3) Continuing from point 5 above - New Content: Every time Arrow Head studios adds something to this game, they somehow break EVERYTHING ELSE. I don't think that they test their new content in a "to scale" manner. I don't know what kind of spaghetti code their hiding under the hood of this game, and at this point I'm afraid to ask.
4) Pointless Mechanics: There are certain mechanics in this game that feel frustratingly pointless. I will use armor rating as an example. The game offers 3 armor tiers: light, medium, and heavy. Light offers the least protection and the greatest movement speed, Medium is in the middle for both, etc. You would think that this further builds on point 2 in the Good section above, adding even more variety to loadouts, right? Not quite. There is basically no reason to wear heavy armor. A lot of the time there is no reason to wear medium armor either. Let's use the Terminids as our example enemy. There is a standard Terminid unit called a Warrior. Wearing medium armor, a warrior can kill you in two hits. Normally, you'd think: "Okay, so medium armor prevents you from dying immediately. That means the armor works right?" No. Warriors can make two attacks almost simultaneously. If you don't either predict a warrior's attack and react before it happens or get lucky, your dead. If you're wearing heavy armor (depending on which set) you may survive with enough health to see the next attack coming. Even so, you aren't guaranteed to survive... which is the entire point of heavy armor. In other words, it probably would have been better to wear light armor and run away. Pretty much anything can be instant death in this game. I often wonder why they even have a health bar. For most of the game your health bar will be in one of two positions: 0% or 100%.
5) The Game Devs: It feels like the Devs want you to suffer sometimes. They love nerfing things. They've mentioned that they want to get rid of the meta and make all weapons/stratagems equally useful, but instead they just keep making everything more useless. It takes all the fun out of the game at times.
6) Cheating Players: There are no repercussions for cheating. The Devs removed the players' ability to report other people for cheating. Some people say that you can report cheaters through a specific support channel on the Arrow Head website, but I haven't been able to find it.

Tangent: The best way to describe this game is that it's more difficult than it was designed to be. If you complain about the difficulty in this game, be ready for the brain dead side of the community to bombard you with "get good" and "play easier mission then, noob". Normally, I'd say that's a reasonable response, but there is actually a decent amount of content you'll never see in this game if you don't play on harder difficulties. Further, even "easy" missions aren't guaranteed to be easier. For some reason certain missions will be way harder than normal with higher enemy spawn rates than there should be. I don't know if this is an intentional game mechanic or a bug that has never been addressed. Sometimes me and a friend can complete level 6's and level 7's with relative ease. Other days, a team of 4 will fail to complete a single objective on a level 5 mission. There's a huge difference between "Wow, this game is difficult" and "I wonder if the level 5 mission is going to feel like a level 8 mission today". Like, if I run off on my own on a level 10 mission with no supplies and a horde of enemies following me and I die, that's one thing. But sometimes I'll be playing a level 3 mission with a good loadout on a low-resistance planet and die 3 times because of circumstances that were completely out of my control, because the enemy spawn rate was randomly set to WUMBO, or because enemies started behaving in ways they shouldn't have.

When you die in a game because of something that was your fault, that's fine. Learn, improve, continue forward. But when you have over 800 hours in the game and that experience means absolutely nothing? When none of the game mechanics are consistent, and every death feels like it was outside of your control? What then? It's grating. It sucks because I REALLY want to love this game, but lately it's just made me want to crash out and rage quit because the game is so unnecessarily abrasive.

Is the game worth it? Bottom Line: If you buy this game, you probably won't regret it. I'd say it's easy enough to get at least $40 worth of entertainment out of this title. However- with the game in its current condition- I can't say that I recommend it. If you crave a challenge give it a try. Be ready for instability and crashes. Be ready for the odds to be against you. You're going to die a lot. A large portion of those deaths will be outside of your control. AH has been doing a lot of work on this game lately, so I'll keep my eye on things and maybe update this review later.

A great game developed by a studio completely incapable of handling its success that prefers to listen to its own opinion instead of listening their players.

I have almost 500h on the game, and I'll start listening the positives:
- Basically impossible to not have a game that is not cinematic. Almost any moment in the game could easily be a cutscene
- Glorious OST, no other way to describe it
- Currently one of the best looking games on the market
- Explosions and guns both sound and look great
- Difficulty spanning from "i just want to mindlessly shoot" to "wtf is happening right now"

And now onto the negatives:
- Weapon balancing
- Performance
- Enemy design
- Bugs
- Co-op features design

But the biggest issues of all, is how the studio is managing all these negatives, that over time have been raised by the player base. To sum up their approach: "I know what you want, you don't". 
I understand some issues are the consequences of the game being planned for a smaller playerbase. Still, the reality is that the game sold a ton, a lot of people like it, and they like something that is VERY different from what the intended vision of the devs was. The devs told multiple times the game was/is supposed to be a grunge fantasy, that "a game for everyone is a game for no-one", that the power fantasy that its intro and trailer sells was supposed to be a joke that you realize playing the game.
To me that's a bunch of nonsense. Everything about the game screams power fantasy, the trailer sold a power fantasy, and people bought it for a power fantasy. And for the past two years that devs have been pin pong-ing between what their users wants, and what they wants. 
People find things they enjoy, the devs find a way to nerf it. In the last patch they got to the point were the community was basically begging to not touch a recent weapons, and they still decided to nerf it, WITHOUT WRITING ON THE PATCH NOTES. Makes you wonder if they think people are stupid. 
People complained of performance issues since last december, of the balooning game size, and they decided to ignore it and continue pumping out content until they got to a point were the crashes were making the game unplayable for a lot of people.

The studio just follow its plans, ignores player feedback 9 of 10 times, and then for that one time rushes to fix. And then the cycle repeats. 
It's basically a meme in the community that this game has cycles of "it's done" and "we are so back". 

If you want to feel like you have the power to fight an entire army just by yourself, it's the best game at giving you that feeling. If you buy into the lore, and find the right people to play it, it becomes one of the best games ever made. But that time you'll have an issue with performance, or an enemy design, or mechanic, don't expect the devs to listen to you. You are just a passive consumer of their product, and for that, I cannot recommend it.

I picked up Elden Ring a while ago, and it completely blew me away.
The world is massive, beautifully crafted, and full of secrets that reward curiosity.
Combat is challenging but fair, giving a true sense of accomplishment with every victory.
The variety of weapons, spells, and builds lets you create a playstyle that feels completely your own.
Exploration is endlessly rewarding — every hidden path or dungeon can lead to epic loot or a tough boss fight.
The bosses are memorable and intimidating, and defeating them is genuinely thrilling.
NPCs and lore are woven into the world in a way that makes every encounter meaningful.
Multiplayer features like co-op and PvP add even more depth and replayability.
The game encourages experimentation and creativity, whether in combat, exploration, or character builds.
If you enjoy challenging, immersive worlds where every step feels earned, Elden Ring is an absolute must-play.

Elden Ring is not just a game; it is the pinnacle of human achievement in interactive art. Dark Souls 1, 2, and 3? Mere warm-ups, clumsy sketches compared to the towering genius of this masterpiece. Lies of P? A pathetic, clumsy echo, utterly incapable of reaching the soaring brilliance of FromSoftware’s vision.

What once might have been friction or tedium in lesser games is here transformed into a seamless, exhilarating flow, where every action and decision hums with brilliance. The world itself anticipates the player, shaping challenges and opportunities with audacious foresight and daring ambition.

Elden Ring doesn’t just surpass the old Souls games - it obliterates them with effortless, godlike mastery, a shining monument to what games can be. 

This is the undisputed apex of human game design. Pack it up. Go home. Give up. Nothing else can even compete. Nothing else will ever approach this level of divine perfection.

Never played a game like this before. So detailed. So beautifully constructed. This was an explorers dream. It was an extremely depressing world, so I'm looking forward to getting back to the Elf worlds I'm used to :-), but I'm super happy that I took the time to give this game a chance. It was extremely addicting, but so very worth it. It deserves all the credit it got. Are there some things I think the devs should bend on, like difficulty levels? Absolutely! Everyone deserves a chance to see this world and they are only doing themselves injustice by alienating those who won't be able to enjoy it due to the difficulty. I don't understand the philosophy of not wanting people to enjoy a world you spent so much time creating, but it is what it is. Anyway, highly recommend, though I'm very late to the game :-).

Elden Ring just blew me away. The world’s huge, gorgeous, and everywhere you turn, there’s something new to stumble into. Every area feels alive, whether you’re creeping through shadowy caves or wandering into towering castles that make you stop and stare.

The combat? It’s brutal, sure, but it always feels fair. Boss fights are wild — you’ll probably curse a lot, but beating one actually feels like you accomplished something. The best part, though, is how you can explore any way you want. No hand-holding, no annoying arrows telling you where to go. Just real, honest adventure.

Yeah, sometimes it’s tough. But that challenge makes every discovery and victory mean more. The music, the world, the whole vibe — it just grabs you. Elden Ring isn’t just another game. It’s a trip you won’t forget.

So far, I have no idea what the hell is happening story-wise - it's pretty confusing. However, the world, the music is breath-taking so it's not difficult to keep on playing just because of that. I strongly believe that as more pieces of the story get revealed, I'll enjoy it even more.

Elden Ring is the rare open world that trusts you. Curiosity is the best stat here—wander off the road and you’ll stumble into dungeons, dragons, and secrets that reshape your build and playstyle. Combat is elastic and expressive: from spellblades and bleed monsters to chunky greatshield tanks, the build variety is wild without feeling gimmicky. The art direction swings from melancholy ruins to nightmare majesty, and it’s unforgettable.

Exploration and initiative are constantly rewarded—knowledge, not just numbers, is your power curve. It’s challenging, yes, but fair in that FromSoftware way that turns setbacks into lore and routing lessons. Simply put: the most generous, surprising, and cohesive take on Souls design to date.

Verdict: The best Souls game ever—vast, intoxicating, and endlessly replayable.
Such an unreal gaming experience, 10/10. Will always love this game

Truthfully, I'm not too sure what I could add that hasn't already been said.
Elden Ring is truly a gem of a product, and one that will keep bringing you make for hours upon hours.

I do think the game can be a bit large for many people. In many other open worlds, I wouldn't think this is a problem, but Elden Ring has so much in it's world. But not only that, since it still can be a bit cryptic with how you moving quest lines along or how to get to certain areas, it can absolutely feel daunting.

This is my second playthrough and I feel much better about this now then my first playthrough. Not only more comfortable with the gameplay and bosses, but being able to traverse the world better. While I didn't know where everything was, it was much easier being able to gauge where things were since I'd played this before.

With that said, it will only effect a small group of people. The rest, well, you have an unbelievably incredible product here. One that you can keep coming back to again-and-again for more. There truly isn't much left to say when talking about this game. Once you play it, you will be entranced and pulled into the world From Software has created once again.

Overall Score: 7/10
Story: 5/10 Story is probably decent, but it never caught my attention, and i half speed ran the start of the game to play with friends missing out of character development etc. 
Gameplay: 9/10 Super solid and consistent gameplay, high difficulty, high challenge but also high rewards.
Graphics: 9/10 The environment, characters and just everything is pretty and looks great.
Solo VS Online: 5/10 Playing this game solo is fun, if you have the mimic tear to assist with boss fights. It's a shame like all souls games the coop portion is pretty terrible. You have to use consumables, stand in specific areas and can wait up to 5 minutes for the signs to spawn in. Just janky, if they can improve it to be similar to the Remnant games etc.
Achievements: 7/10 Complete the game and do all bosses, then collectables towards the end. Score drops a couple of times as you have to complete the game multiple times for different endings.

Horrendous game. Stylish and pretty with some of the most horrid mechanics of ANY game I've played. Every Single Enemy has AOE's that are either A. Unavoidable or last an arbitrary amount of time unable for you do deal damage to, Flying enemies unable to be hit unless you're using a specific weapon ( in which case this goes against EVERYTHING ) every other Souls game did where you should and could use EVERY weapon and it be viable. Not here. Want to use Fist weapons? you'll never land a hit on anything that flies at any point. Want to try do some roll playing and sneaking around to do some cheap critical hits? have fun during boss fights. Want to challenge yourself and use ONLY consumables? can't do that either since you can only hold so many of 1 item at a time. Buffs don't last over 60 seconds where fights with bosses and demi-bosses can last over 5x - 10x that amount of time. add in the AOE fiasco that every enemy can do and maneuver during their "I'm going to enrage so don't come near me for 20 seconds ) makes them feel underwhelming and useless. Many late game bosses have this issue not just the early game. The copying and pasting of bosses in the game can make some sense to a degree, but there are literal areas just filled with what you fought somewhere 1 on 1 and now you have to 1 v 6 them. it's lazy, uninteresting and no-one goes out of their way to fight them. This game is literally marathon simulator, run past everything go to the next area to get your upgrade materials then go back since leveling your actual stats outside of Vigor, Endurance and Mind have little on how much damage you deal. Oh you wanted to maybe change your build mid way through then change it back? well you have to play though an entire area first unlike in DS2 you can do it immediately at the start of the game. I've never heard anyone say they enjoy fighting enemies like the Ulcerated Tree Spirits, Fighting 2 or more Crystallid Warriors or Crucible Knights ( even though if you just blaze through the game with max upgraded weapons or as far as you can get them they're not horrible ). Bosses should be just that "Bosses" not just something you copy and paste like 15 other enemies in the game and just be like here you go, we ran out of ideas just stick something in it. As someone who's put 1000+ hours into DS1 and DS2 and a couple of hundred in DS3 back on Xbox 360 this game is exactly what every bad thing about all of those games was and put into this one. Poise means nothing and weight means everything. Heavy armor is worthless and serves no purpose but to slow you down. Got headbutted by a 3 foot tall plant? Literally wearing stone as armor enjoy being stun locked and losing 20% of your health since damage reduction is % based you can't tell me that 1.6% of 1500 damage has any difference than 3.2% of 1500 damage means you're going to live or die in a boss fight that's going to take 10 minutes anyway ( i'll do the math here for you, it's less than 50 overall damage that you'd receive ) ( every dragon in the game follows this principle ). People that have praised this game are deluded in game and world design. Beat the game and i'll never touch it again dropped it a year ago back in august and picked it up after some tweaks were made came back ran a train on everything then you get to the last 5 - 6 bosses you can encounter where it's a 10 - 15 minute kite festival trying to squeeze in a hit without getting punished for it. Save your money and your sanity. stay far away it. The best description i can find for this game is and pun intended a Shattered Masterpiece.

I held off playing this game for so long because of the initial bad reviews and bugs, but as of today this is probably one of the best games currently out. It is difficult to say enough good about it. 

For someone older, who struggles with an open world game that is TOO OPEN, this combination of linear story with an incredible open world setting really hits it for me. Reminds me of RDR2 in that sense. 

The story is incredible, the choices that you make as you play are super important and it really feels like everyone gets a different experience. 

The menu and navigation takes a bit to get used to and the cyberware system definitely required a bit of a read up but once you understand it, it is a really unique aspect of an RPG. 

The soundtrack is amazing and atmospheric, the combat is slick and fun, honestly it is a 10/10 game and an absolute MUST PLAY

Wanna clarify that I've only finished about 2 of the base game endings and have a ton of other side gigs left to do. I also have a degree of bias due to being pretty involved in the punk scene already. Even then, I still HAVE to recommend this. I have never felt so embraced by such a unique, stunning world with a wild cast of characters. 
Combat never felt too boring, even with me going for a simple 'blunt object' build. I do wish the better rewards for missions didn't feel so based in stealth, but I think it's encouraged me to do a netrunner playthrough next. And even when I didn't want to start a fight, just driving around the city with the radio on was enough. 
Regarding the narrative, Night City will give you the exact amount of immersion you want, provided you're willing to give it time to build up steam. Once you cross that line, it's hard not to get sucked in. And without giving anything away in the plot, you will constantly be questioning your moral code. Every ending has its caveat. Every character will have their impact.
My journey started getting a bit buggy towards the end, but otherwise it ran pretty smoothly. Most issues ended up being in regards to driving (AutoDrive would fail to start properly unless I rebooted the game, or my car would clip through the ground). Other simple bugs involved missing audio during dialogue. Still annoying, but honestly, I'm impressed it took 50 hours to even see a single bug. Everything was smooth before that.
Considering how terrible this game supposedly was at launch, the fact that the game is doing this well today is genuinely impressive. It 100% has a place within my top 5 favorite games of all time. And even then, it's likely #1 or #2.
So glad I waited until they fixed the game and played it as it should be played. It's a amazing game and it has a interesting and we'll written story.
I never used fast travel even once - the city is just too beautiful and too immersive to miss that

good story

Ultimately hints a very good lesson on the overview of life, immortality, the fleeting dream.
To seek freedom, implies the state of captivity. 

The entire world generally feels alive and immersive. The design aesthetics and whole live city is visually spectacular.
The characters are memorable, for good or bad... the people are as crazy as would be expected in a godless society.
There are no rules in the city and anything can happen. Trust is hard to build where lies beget truth. True survival of the fittest atmosphere. Everyone looks out for themselves and figuring out if there's a purpose, meaning. or evolution to their existence in a pyramid city where anything is possible. Without giving any real spoiler, one eventually finds the entire thing extremely dystopian and depressing. But then again that's up to how you want to interpret your story....

Combat is intriguing and unpredictable op at times. It may be familiar to Fallout series combat, but this is much more invested. (however, shared similar clunk animations)

A downside is no aliens/bio species even though in the future.
Biggest downside is playing as a named character, so there's a lack of personal touch.

Hard scale rating: an 80 out of 100 (Legendary tier)
P.S. I played this game for awhile even if steam didn't log it for some reason.

Cyberpunk, oh Cyberpunk... The game that turned my online game addiction into a singleplayer addiction. I'm not quite sure what to say though, did I love it? Definitely. Do I recommend it? Absolutely. Will I replay it? Without a doubt. I mean, the game has its flaws and it had even more before. But the experience in it's current state is fenomenal from start - to finish. Especially with the addition of Phantom Liberty (DLC). So if you are a fan of RPG's and FPS's, I'd definitely say "Give it a try!"

Finally got Cyberpunk when it was randomly on sale in late 2025... really happy I picked it up. It's fantastic, and there's not a whole lot of of bugs or jank left in the game. A very fun experience with lots of still novel concepts, despite being ~5 years old.

I enjoy that there are actually multiple ways to approach situations depending on your skill distribution, without fully locking you out of doing anything. Would be pretty awful to hardlock you out of certain quests/objectives if you didn't have strength of an arbitrary threshold to bash in a door -- the game offers a path regardless of your build, which is nice. Those alternate paths are also not just side-by-side BS "options" (e.g., hack the access panel that is right next to the door you can break that is next to a vent you can stealthily enter)... there's slightly more detouring involved around each option, to the point where you have to seek out the option that jives with your build.

Weapons mechanics are solid, especially with the tech / power / smart dynamics, though I feel like diversity of guns is skewed towards pistols / SMGs / Assault rifles mainly... would have loved a wider range offering of precision & sniper rifles. Shotguns are actually well represented with double barrel, semi-auto, and heavy variants. Tech weapons feel a bit underwhelming, but that just might be due to my current build.

World feels very full & immersive, and has pretty good exploration -- you get locked into the initial area/district for the first prologue portion of the game, and then it eventually opens up the rest of the map. I like that you unlock fast travel points via proximity rather than having to actively click on them. I don't like the pacing of certain quests where it's locked around "xyz will call you later after you've done more side gigs / missions".

I've put in 100+ hours within a month of buying, so I think that speaks for itself.

Running a 7950X3D, 7900XT, and 32 gb RAM @ 1440p... ultra settings across the board, with the exception of ray tracing. I'm using whatever AMD frame generation stuff is default.

5/5, would Cyberpunk again.

Cyberpunk 2077 Review 
Gameplay
*  Massive overhaul in Update 2.0 — combat, perks, and cyberware feel fresh and balanced.
* Gunplay is tight and responsive; melee finally feels impactful.
* Hacking system is deeper and more tactical — rewarding stealth players.
* Vehicle combat and police chases add excitement missing from the original launch.
* Builds matter now — you can truly feel the difference between Netrunner, Solo, or Tech builds.

 World & Exploration
* Night City is breathtaking — dense, detailed, and alive with atmosphere.
* NPCs and crowds behave more realistically after updates.
* Side missions and gigs often rival main quests in writing and world-building quality.
* Vertical design (rooftops, alleys, interiors) encourages exploration like never before.

Story & Characters
* V’s story remains emotional and personal — full of tough choices.
*  Johnny Silverhand (Keanu Reeves) is charismatic and complex.
* Multiple endings still hit hard — now with more context and improved pacing.

Performance & Graphics
* Major technical improvements — stable, optimized, and smooth on PC & consoles.
* Ray tracing + DLSS 3.5 (PC) make visuals stunning.
*  Most bugs and crashes are gone; gameplay is consistent.
* Feels truly *next-gen* now — not the broken launch version from 2020.


Final Verdict
Story & Characters:9.5 / 10
World Design:9 / 10
Gameplay & Combat: 9 / 10
Performance & Stability: 8.5 / 10
Sound & Atmosphere:10 / 10

Overall Score:9 / 10

Most of us remember the launch of Cyberpunk 2077 back in December 2020; Undelivered promises regarding content, bugs/glitches, technical issues etc. All these problems made me postpone my purchase of the game. I eventually bought the game in June 2022 but still I was unsure whether the game was worth my time and if all the major problems were fixed. The game waited for 3 more years in my library. 

May 2025 I finally forced myself to start a playthrough and oh boy was I positively surprised. This is truly one of the best games I've experienced in my life. The sounds and looks of the city were just what I would have expected a futuristic city to sound and look like. Gameplay was interesting, character builds had diversity and the story was captivating. I enjoyed every minute of the game and 100%:ed the game including achievements. 

The story made me feel and think. I was immersed in the game world it and felt the weight of responsibility for the decisions I made. 

I highly suggest you to play Cyberpunk 2077 and its Phantom Liberty DLC.

After playing this game for quite some time, I can easily say this game is a masterpiece. The game has truly come a long way since release back in 2020. The main story is one of the most engaging, immersive and emotional experiences I’ve personally experienced in gaming. Every choice feels meaningful, every mission pushes you deeper into the world of Night City weather its a story mission or side quest/gig. The writing just hits different and It’s a perfect mix of action, emotion, and pure atmosphere.

You'll meet many unique characters but there were specifically 2 that stuck out to me which were Johnny and Panam. Johnny Silverhand, hes much more than just a side character, he’s the soul of this story. You’ll hate him, respect him, and eventually understand him. Panam Palmer brings a different level of emotion to the game every scene with her feels alive,  real, and full of heart. Her story is a roller-coaster of adrenaline, family, loyalty, and steamy romance (if you play male V). 

Then comes Phantom Liberty...it somehow it raises the bar even higher. The writing, the tension, the moral choices, it’s peak storytelling and really dives into the underworld of how twisted night city is. Even at the top of your game in this dlc you face many difficult choices regarding "moral vs reason." Every choice comes at a price as the story unfolds. From the start Reed and Songbird tone of the story perfectly. Both their roles in the story keeps you questioning loyalty, trust and survival. You’ll constantly wonder who’s telling the truth and what it means to do the right thing. 

I would 100% recommend this game, its truly amazing and worth a shot.

When Cyberpunk 2077 first dropped in December 2020, it was one of the most anticipated releases of the decade — and one of the most infamous at launch. But after years of patches, updates, and a stellar expansion (Phantom Liberty), CD Projekt Red has finally delivered the game fans always dreamed of.
What started as a technical mess has evolved into one of the most immersive sci-fi RPGs ever made.

After years of patches, Cyberpunk 2077 finally lives up to its potential. It’s a dark, emotional, and deeply immersive RPG that rewards exploration, choice, and reflection. The world-building is unmatched, and with Phantom Liberty, it cements itself as one of the best sci-fi stories in gaming.

Really impossible to do anything but give it a big thumbs up. I avoided this game for years due to the disastrous launch. As of now, I can confidently say that whatever rough experience people had with Cyberpunk 2077 are not the experience that the game presents today. 

The stories, quests and characters are very well written. There are endearing, funny, introspective moments and everything inbetween, all tastefully written. The world building does an amazing job of presenting us a grim reality where morality is diluted as technology advances farther than what we as humans can rationalize.

The art direction is great, Night City looks great. Character's faces are what impressed me the most. Probably the best I've seen so far in a game. The lighting is also very well done: the way it reflects on objects in the world really surprises us, as players, with beautiful moments in the most unexpected ways.

In terms of gameplay, it's still pretty good, especially considering it's an open-world RPG of such huge size. However, this is where, for me, the downsides begin. The combat was alright (I played mostly a sword-wielding character, and had a lot of fun slicing and dicing, and they even let you block and reflect back enemie's bullets, which was awesome; parrying does a cool slow motion effect). However, I felt gunplay wasn't particular satisfying. What impressed me the least was the driving, which felt clunky and unresponsive at times.

Another criticism I have is the lack of NPC reactions to what you do. There are a lot of pedestrian NPCs just walking around, hanging about, which does help the world come alive at first glance. However, the way they just stand around a bit and don't really interact with you and each other, kind of makes the open world feel a bit hollow. Another thing that bothered me was how characters from quests, which have fleshed out personalities and dialogues, just stand there after they're done talking to you. Like after being sent off to do something, they'll then just stand there waiting for you to go, and there's no way to interact at all, ask them anything, etc. Especially with Johnny, who shows up a lot of times and will often just stand there staring at you. Having a line that you can say to him and repeat if necessary would, in my opinion, go a long way into making it so that NPCs don't feel like they're just there to deliver something to you.

In conclusion, I'll say again that Cyberpunk 2077 absolutely delivers a meaningful experience, which is an adjective that I don't usually attribute to games, or entertainment in general, and as such, absolutely worth it if you're looking for a more involved type of game.

I have put a huge amount of time into this game by this point (both unmodded and modded). Regardless of its buggy launch, I think the game is in a great state now. I enjoy the gameplay a lot, it feels like a nice mix of RPG and Immersive Sim, which is a genre I love. I love the characters and the story. Some of the writing has had a big impact on me.

It's the world that always brings me back, though. Night City is truly just something else, the scale and density and layers of it, it [i]feels[/i] like the cyberpunk dystopian city that it is. It's easy to get lost in it just walking around, and there's a feeling when you watch an NPC leave or you go around a corner like they've just disappeared into this vast jungle of neon and metal. It's intimidating in the best way, and the city just won't leave my brain. Whether it's the staggring skyscrapers and waterfalls of neon adorning them, or the quiet badlands and their open sky interrupted with babel-esque towers of advertising, well, I'll let Jackie say it.

Wow. Bought on sale solely to scratch an itch for dystopian punk vibes, ended up sitting in silence staring at a black screen as electric cello ripped my heart into little bits. Games are usually fun, sometimes impactful; this story hits you like a gut punch and doesn't let you forget it. The gameplay is fresh and dynamic and leaves so many options for how you choose to approach it. The world isn't just immersive, there are times it feels like a real place somewhere. Don't even get me started on the voice acting. No matter what life path and choices you go with, you cant escape the emotional weight of Cyberpunk 2077. I got so lost in the story that V wasn't my character, they were ME and I was V. Your choices actually matter, and you feel every single one. The world is so massive and detailed, endless possibilities for exploration and storylines you never even notice on your first playthrough. This review would be an essay if I didn't cut myself short, so here's my best summary:

- Leaves you with real, deep emotions (and crippling depression) and thoughts that you simply don't forget
- Thrusts you into a deep, detailed, immersive world that swallows you whole and never really lets you go
- Voice acting gives you chills, and the soundtrack makes you feel things no video game should be able to
- Engaging, intuitive, and enjoyable gameplay mechanics and so much variety and diversity in approaches

Won't just replay this again, I will remember every single new story I write through V's eyes in the absurd and beautiful Night City.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a masterpiece that has left an indelible mark on the video game industry. Since its release, it has been acclaimed for its deep and complex narrative that transports players to a dystopian future where technology and humanity intertwine in fascinating and often unsettling ways. Night City, the main setting, is a character in itself: vibrant, dangerous, and full of life and secrets. Its urban design, blending futuristic architecture with echoes of the past, creates a unique and captivating atmosphere. The attention to detail in every corner of the city from the glowing neon lights to the dark alleys invites exploration and discovery. The environments are so rich and diverse that each district has its own identity, from the luxurious skyscrapers of the corporate zone to the slums where survival is a daily struggle.The freedom of choice that Cyberpunk 2077 offers is another one of its greatest strengths. Players can shape their experience through their decisions, affecting not only the main narrative but also the world around them. This ability to influence the story creates a sense of agency rarely found in other games, allowing for multiple playthroughs without ever feeling repetitive. The consequences of your actions are tangible and often unexpected, adding another layer of depth to the experience. For example, choosing to help a side character might open new opportunities or close others making every decision truly matter.
The characters in Cyberpunk 2077 are memorable and deeply developed. From the protagonist, V, to Johnny Silverhand, masterfully portrayed by Keanu Reeves, every character has clear motivations and a well defined narrative arc. The supporting cast is also meticulously crafted, each with their own story that contributes to the rich tapestry of the game’s world. The chemistry between characters and the dynamics of their relationships add an emotional depth that enriches the narrative. Keanu Reeves, in particular, brings a charismatic presence that elevates the entire experience.The visual design of the game is simply stunning. The art direction is an achievement in itself, creating a city that feels both futuristic and nostalgic. The lighting effects, color palette, and futuristic architecture come together to create a visual experience that is both beautiful and oppressive. Every corner of Night City feels alive filled with energy and activity constantly inviting players to explore and uncover its secrets. The attention to detail in the visual effects, such as raindrops sliding down windows or neon lights reflecting on puddles, is breathtaking. It’s as if every pixel was carefully placed to create a truly immersive experience.
Character customization is another one of Cyberpunk 2077’s greatest strengths. Players have a wide range of options to create their ideal version of V, from appearance to abilities. This customization extends to gameplay style, allowing players to tailor their approach based on their preferences whether it’s hacking, melee combat, or gunfights. The freedom of choice in customization not only adds depth to the game but also lets players experiment with different playstyles and discover new strategies. You can be a lethal mercenary, a master hacker, or a balanced mix of both, and each path offers a unique experience.The soundtrack is a masterpiece on its own. Featuring a selection of music that ranges from electronic to rock, every track is carefully chosen to complement the game’s atmosphere. The voice acting and performances especially from well-known actors are top notch, enhancing the narrative and immersing players even deeper into the world of Cyberpunk. The soundtrack doesn’t just accompany the action; it reflects the mood and emotions of the characters, adding another layer of immersion. I remember one particular mission where the pulsating electronic music kept me on the edge of my seat during an intense chase.
The side missions in Cyberpunk 2077 are another major highlight. Each one is carefully crafted, offering rich storytelling and memorable characters. These missions don’t just add hours of gameplay they deepen the world of Cyberpunk, revealing more of its stories and secrets. The variety of side quests ensures there’s something for everyone, from hacking jobs to combat missions to exploration-based tasks. Each side mission is so well-built that it often feels like a short film within the game. One of my favorites was the mission where I had to infiltrate a corporation to steal sensitive data the tension and strategy involved made every moment thrilling.The open world of Night City is visually stunning, bursting with atmosphere and detail. The freedom to explore allows players to lose themselves in its streets and uncover hidden secrets. The city feels alive, populated with characters ranging from the humble to the powerful, each with their own story to tell. The interaction with NPCs is rich and varied, allowing for deep and often surprising conversations. I remember once meeting an old man in an alley who shared a touching story about his life in Night City moments like that make the game’s world feel truly alive and real.
The gameplay offers a wide range of options, from hacking to melee combat and gunfights. Character customization is extensive, allowing players to tailor their playstyle to their preferences. The freedom of choice in side missions and the ability to shape the story based on your decisions are key strengths that make every player’s experience unique. The depth of customization and freedom of choice ensures that each playthrough feels distinct. You can decide how to approach every situation, and each decision carries consequences that impact your progress throughout the game. In summary, Cyberpunk 2077 is a monumental achievement in the world of video games. With its rich narrative, memorable characters, stunning visual design, and freedom of choice, it delivers a truly unique and profound experience. It’s a game that fans of science fiction and open world RPGs should not miss. Cyberpunk 2077 not only sets a new standard for open world games but also opens the door to new possibilities in interactive storytelling and the exploration of virtual worlds.

[h1]A+++ Must Play[/h1]

I've played this on PS4, PS5, and now I can say I've played it on Steam. Am I obsessed? Mad? Have more money than sense? Perhaps. But just like those old ads about how Snickers satisfies, this game well and truly satisfies.

Cherami Leigh voices the female version of the main character, and Keanu Reeves voices the antagonist. I say antagonist, not villain. That is someone else. But between these two, I feel like Cyberpunk is brought to life like no other game has for me in the past. Apparently Keanu liked the role so much he asked for more. Cherami's voice seems so full of emotion and desperation that I have to pinch myself, tell myself it isn't real. Because it seems so real...

Hand-in-hand with great voice acting is the eye-candy visuals of a 2077 gone mad. The game is chock full of detail! Neon lights, people with body modifications (cyberware), weather effects, streets full of garbage and vending machines, winding confusing roads snaking back on themselves, over and under, merging and separating. Various gangs, corporations, individuals. It's almost a child-like wonder just to look around, marvel at the experience.

Part of the charm of this game is the interactions between V and your antagonist, Johnny Silverhand (Keanu). Through a bizarre set of circumstances you are stuck on a journey through life together, a journey through death. So many magical epiphanies, realisations, sacrifices. The endings hit HARD, but the main game endings are where it is at. While Phantom Liberty has some great endings as well, I don't like the additional 'V' ending.

There's a lot to do in the game. With enough content to rival most RPGs of yesteryear, you'll easily rack up 200 hours or more just to get through everything (a little less for me this time due to 3rd playthrough). There are cars to steal (if you have the dlc), lots of side gigs, various main missions and multiple endings. There are cyberpsychos to subdue, lots of skills to max out, various character builds to explore, and various tactics to take advantage of. Weapons can be upgraded, weapon mods can be upgraded - even your cyberware can be upgraded and enhanced with modifiers, which you get some limited control over if you build your character right.

Play styles vary from pistols, to machine guns, snipers, shotguns, revolvers, or even blunt weapons, or swords... you can even forego combat altogether and try to get through the game using just your cyberdeck, and stealth takedowns. 

Additional features (this is by no means all of them) include slow motion buffs, monowires, gorilla claws, or even overclocking your cyberware, and even smart weapons that can fire homing shots. 

There are so many options of how to play the game that there is sure to be something for everyone. And with no achievements being difficulty-specific, it doesn't matter what you use. Everything is effective.


But are there any negatives? Any hitches or problems?

I've found extended play sessions can cause the game to hang and close, so perhaps there's a memory leak. Occasionally there would be loot issues, for example weapons stuck under destroyed vehicles, I once had a policeman standing half in the pavement but this had no effect on anything. Also I feel I should caution against driving super fast - depends on your settings and rig of course, but you might put unnecessary strain on your system as the game struggles to keep loading textures and objects. Best thing to do is only max your settings for photo mode.

Sadly there isn't much in the way of 3rd-person cutscenes, so no matter how pretty or cool you make your protagonist, you won't see him or her much. Some endings will let you see your V talk, show emotions. Motorbikes are a good idea if you want to see your toon. Also, photo mode is kind of restrictive - most story moments would not let the camera free from 1st person view, so that is a bit of a let down.


As an overall experience, and taking into account replayability, Cyberpunk 2077 is an overwhelming success. Even the few problems you might encounter are miniscule when weighed against the sheer enjoyment the game has to offer.

Final warning though, if you don't like swearing then this game might not be for you :(

Well at the risk of this review getting buried during the review-bomb/controversy. I still have to say it... this game, "Devotion," is ACTUALLY amazing. 

If I can give a surface level description of this game, think of "Layers of Fear" and the pros and cons of that game; but with a more compelling and tragic story.  In the very least it has an actual ending. And the build up to that ending was... *sniffles*... lets just say after playing the game I had to get up from my computer to walk around, contemplating life and it's frailties. 

I enjoyed "Layers of Fear" so I can look past some of the cons in that one, like it being a 'walking sim.' However the only downside, for me personally, is that in the game you walk pretty slowly (there isn't a quicker pace/jog button). 

It is also important to note that this game is 2 to 3 hours long, which is fine. The game was as long as it needed to be to tell its story.

If you have time to burn or it's near Halloween, I fully recommend  this walk into the depths of despair that is "Devotion."

It's not a political satire nor a boring propaganda. RedCandleGames merely want to tell us a story about a broken family.
In the end, you may find out the truth.

(***Containing Spoilers***) 
So, this is going to be a rather long and tedious explanation on the political crapstorm for you folks who don't know Chinese. I'll try to be as neutral as possible. 
Players found a seal of the in-game cult which has 'winnie the pooh' and 'Xi Jingping' on it. Later some PRC ‘patriot’ alerted the public and government body on social media. Most Taiwanese think the mainlander were triggered because they are brainwashed to support their leader, however this is not quite the case. While some so called 'patriots' indeed got triggered by that, the majority are not too bothered by that. Most mainlanders are triggered because after this discovery, a lot of the seemingly non-political things in this game start to make sense in a political way.  They start to see proofs that this game hides suggestive insults to the general public in the mainland. 
This game is about a cult, the cult leader's name has the exact same pronunciation as  'Mainland citizen'. If you know Chinese you know there are four or more tones for the same syllable, even the tones are the same in this case. Then the cult itself is named 'lu xin she', 'da lu' ('the mainland') is the general term for the mainland. 'xin' is 'heart' or 'mind' in Chinese. 'she' is a society. So basically people interpret this cult is as a metaphor of those who supports the mainland. The victim in this game is named 'Mei Xin'. 'Mei' generally means beauty, but it is also the name of America ('Mei Guo', emit the 'guo' for country.) So people interpreted this as 'the heart for America'. So this all starts to make sense to the mainland audience as a narrative of 'Mainland citizens' and the 'people who supports mainland' prosecute the 'desire/heart/support for America'. Which the mainland audience felt is clearly a separatism agenda. The cult sacrificial day is set on October 1st to 7th (This October is not the lunar October, lunar October 1st would make sense in this case because traditionally lunar October 1st is a day to make offering to the dead), just happens to be the PRC National Foundation day and its public holiday.  The cult candles also adds up to 49, 1949 October 1st is the foundation day of PRC. Now I personally don't know if the team really was targeting the mainland audience or not. I personally doubt it is, because this is wayyy too obvious. This would be like a 12 years old thinks god emperor Trump meme is top notch political commentary. On the other hand red candle had shown particular attention to the use of date and details before, you can read more about the various dates in detention. Very few Taiwanese seems to mention this, the ones who mentioned it dismissed it as baseless speculations, but that's probably the major reason that many former mainland fans lost faith in the developer as they see it as a direct insult to the common people, not just the government. Many mainland gamers also worry that such a politically sensitive game could trigger a knee jerk reaction from the Chinese government to completely ban steam all together.
This whole situation sparked a full-on online war between mainlanders and Taiwanese. The investors and publisher have all backed off and cut ties, the studio is under quite a crisis now. Their mainland social media account is deleted, the game is pull off from Chinese steam. PRC gamers started a massive review bombing campaign on the game. Some made fake screenshot and other materials to 'prove' the studio's supposed sinister intent. While some bought the game only to leave a negative review before they ask for refund. The rating dropped from overwhelmingly positive to mixed in a matter of hours. Many influencer and streamer who previously gave condolences to the game now has either cut ties or actively express their discontent. The studio has come out with various apologise and declaration statements to no avail, only to fuel the conflict even further. According to the team, the cult seal is a mistake left accidentally in by one of the graphic designers, who used popular online slangs as testing material. The mainland gamers don't believe this at all and insist the studio itself is responsible for their hidden political agenda. They also believe the studio only apologised because they are still interested in the mainland market, which only angered the gamers more. On the Taiwanese side it triggered a wave of negative attitude towards mainland gamers. There are already quite a lot of anti-mainland and dependence sentiments, especially after Xi mentioned that the PRC government will still consider military unification an option in this lunar new year's open letter to public. The reactions from mainland gamers only dragged their already negative view of mainland public into an abysmal level.  They can't understand the overreaction and they think to keep pushing and prosecute the studio after the apology is very unreasonable. Many despise what they regard as overly politically sensitive, and self-censoring mainlanders. From their perspective, it's very hypocritical of the mainlanders to promote the game as a 'homemade game' at the start then quickly turn 180 and condemn it once this shitstorm blows out. There are also cracked pirate version of the game already circulating in mainland websites despite the price is half of its international price in PRC.
OK that's pretty much it. I hope this long and boring explanation shed a bit light for you confused bystanders. I personally think the game is decent. I don't see any suggestive theme outside of the supposed metaphoric names.  This is NOT a review for the game however, this is my mere attempt to help people to understand the situation. Some details may be completely wrong, but this is my understanding of the situation. Have a nice day and pet a puppy today :)

Ignoring the blatant Chinese trolls triggered by the fact that not many folks like Xi Jingping, the game takes place in 80's Taiwan, which can be best described in game (and this is a major part of the story so I won't spoil anything) as where modernity and tradition are in constant conflict. Devotion has you play as a man looking for his daughter, while trying to piece together your own past on the events leading up to her daughter's disappearance. I won't give anything away, but this is a story where the main protagonist is basically a tragic figure.

Graphic wise, the game runs really smoothly, even on a old graphics card like mine (AMD Radeon R7 200 series) so there is no need to worry about it bonking your system.

It must be nice to be a political leader who has such an indoctrinated group of followers that they are willing to jump on anyone who criticizes you like a pack of wolves, and who boycott products with the slightest whiff of political sentiment that disagrees with their own. 

I can't help notice the similarities to President Trump's supporters in the US. Authoritarianism does well by such people, who are so willing to divide the world into friends and foes of their particular ideology, art and creativity and nuance be damned. But I digress:

I really enjoyed Red Candle's previous game, Detention so I was hyped about this game. Man did they deliver! It's a massive graphic upgrade from Detention yet the same unique horror vibe carried over. Sure the jump scares are sometimes cheesy but there's more to the game that chills you to the bone. Of course what makes this game special is the Chinese culture aspect, which is rarely represented in horror games, or video games in general.

OK now on to the elephant in the room: the "politically motivated" image. Sure it doesn't add anything to the game but I don't think it deserves the negativity and uhm, rage. As a mainland-born Chinese, I find it funny and sad that some of my fellow people can't take something directed at a political figure (whether Xi is evil is not even relevant). I thought I had read enough dystopian fiction on how oppressive regimes can transform the people but this is even beyond the imagination of literature. I understand the part where they fear this may get the game, or even the entirety of Steam, banned given the current atmosphere against video games in China. For that reason I think Red Candle Games made a poor choice: not that they are not entitled to expressing themselves but as I said they included something that didn't add anything to the game theme. However, I do want to say to the players who share that fear: you should realize it is the government bodies that impose censorship, not the artist themselves. Playing "safe" may buy you a sense of safety, but not really.

Devotion is a wonderful game, the story in my opinion was quite amazing. But however, the game is quite short, and the devs seem to have realized this. The game is artificially lengthened, in quite a few ways. 
-Long corridors
-slow walking speed
-Long corridors that make you walk even slower
All this to make the game longer, so people can't get a refund, I feel like I did not get my money's worth on this game, and I recommend you buy this game on sale. 
Now, on to the horror aspect. This game does have some moments that are quite nerve wracking, but it felt like they're few and far between, and any moments that are meant to be scary I was often met with a jumpscare- which only about two of them successfully made me jump. But all others I *knew* was going to happen and made the game less scary for me, I am of the belief that a psychological horror should not rely on jumpscares to scare the player, as I felt this game did. BUT despite the reliance on jumpscares I will say the moments that did have tension- were very well done. 
TLDR: Artificially lengthened, Story is great, couple jumpscares- could be done better imo, BUY ON SALE!!!

Good game, suffers from being compared to Detention but still has enough of its own identity to succeed. Unlike Detention the ending is pretty obvious from the word "go" just from well worn horror tropes, but that's not really what we are here for. We're unpacking why those events happened, and the world that caused those issues. The design can be a bit confusing at times, especially one point where you get a variety of places to go and each one can change arbitrarily, but overall it's pretty good at subtly telegraphing where you are supposed to go. I do think that the switch to first person is to the benefit of the game, a third person Detention-esque style would not have allowed you to see the small details that makes the apartments feel more lived-in and alive.

There is a lot of untranslated Mandarin in the game but it's all secondary stuff, I played with my mandarin-speaking wife and we didn't find anything that would cause an issue for english-only speakers.

As for the obvious review bombs, I wonder if these people have even played Detention because they would probably find that massively more offensive than a joke about Xi Jinping. Hopefully one day Taiwan and China, separate countries, can get along.

Game itself is a solid horror game that has good story that is very related to Asian families.

Love the details of the artwork and story line. The translation is also on point given that a lot of the specific terms for the Chinese rituals are extremely hard to be explained to a non-Chinese audience without writing an essay about it.
The music, especially the ending credit and theme songs, fits the atmosphere so well that I couldn't stop looping it in my head.
It was not as scary as I thought (i.e. not many jumpscares or gore), but it's definitely creepy af. It's that type of games that keeps you awake at night.
For those who are worrying about the short gameplay: don't rush it through, take your time to absorb the Taiwanese culture in the 80's and learn the backstory. It's gonna be much scarier when you could immerse yourself in that place in time where people were blinded by their own superstition (well, ironically that's exactly what happened to this game recently).
Overall, money and time well spent. Look forward to the next game by Red Candle!

I won't be lying if I say I decided to check this game out purely because of a certain Easter egg.

What you get in the package is your typical spooky walking simulator, albeit with an interesting flavor that Asian culture gives it. You'll find yourself asking whether it is you (the protagonist) is simply going through insanity and coping with his loss, or these things do happen for real. Maybe I didn't read all in-game notes crucial to the story, but you don't get an actual closure to the story. Only symbolism, which there are lots of in Devotion. I also kinda liked that 2D platformer section, which could be a game of its own. Also, the artstyle of the ending sequence. It's really gorgeous.

In my opinion, however, the game would have been way better if the developers went with psychological horror genre and didn't include jumpscares. These were really annoying. Otherwise the game is fine if you're into that kind of games.
