An fantastic horror game developed by a Taiwanese team. Even though I am not a person who likes horror game, especially the one including jump scares, the sound effect and art design in Devotion are wonderful. Red candle perfectly reappears Taiwanese society in 1980s. 

Unfortunately, this game is receiving an uncountable negative review left by Chinese player. The reason was an in-game charm said, “Xi Jinping Winnie the Pooh Moron”. Since Red Candle received the report by the player on Feb 21, they fixed the charm immediately (v1.0.5). However, the most of Chinese player has downloaded the "pirated" Devotion. Therefore, the charm mistake couldn't be fixed since it can't update by Steam. The charm incidence makes the majority of Chinese player keep abusing this wonderful game and say it hides an ideology of "pro-Taiwan independence". Moreover, another game produced by Red Candle in 2017, Detention, is receiving critical common as well.

On the released date of Devotion, the streamers all around the world has opened the live stream, including Chinese players. Since most of the Chinese people think Taiwan is a part of China, they added "Domestic game" on the title of their stream. However, after the charm incidence, Devotion, any related video and discussion were banned in China with the following criticisms to Red Candle. In order to express their anger, Chinese players malicious left negative reviews to pull down the rating. In my opinion, it is irrational and ridiculous. I still see people discussing Devotion on social media, opening stream on Youtube and reading the article about the meaning behind the game. Therefore, it is an evidence to prove that Taiwan is an independent country with the freedom and democracy.

Last time, Red Candle told us the White Horror happened in 1950s, taught us to cherish the freedom and democratic society we have today. This time, they are going to bring you to 80s. Through the investigation in the old apartment, you gonna discover how the pure paternal love and the superstition lead the story to a tragic ending.

As a Taiwanese, I hope the players from other country can give a try to this amazing game which made by Taiwanese team.

Thank you Red Candle, looking forward to your next product :)

More details about the charm incidence: https://www.spieltimes.com/news/xi-jinping-winnie-the-pooh-moron-found-in-devotion-game-is-being-review-bombed-by-chinese-players/

This is the best horror game I've ever played in my life. The details in scene threw me back to my childhood at Taiwan, give it the phone, TV, radio, photo / posts on the wall, chairs... all the things. The sound effect is also the best, give it the background sound of typhoon nights, the bird tweeting door bell sound, water bowling pot, and again, all of these are just like coming out of real life memory. The music is also the best, such as Lady of the pier, it's a lovely song that I cannot stop listen to it again and again. And talking about the story, it's yet another best thing I've ever seen. Personally I went through many of the struggles and the emotional up and down people had in the game plot, I can totally feel the way the character felt in the game. While this may seem like just a horror game, there are some really deep meaning behind it. Anyway, if you enjoy horror game, this is something you must play.

[b]Devotion[/b] is a true [b]masterpiece[/b], whether on its story, graphics, atmosphere, music or the details on religious and background of TW. I have played games with good contents, graphics or good atmospheres. Please ignore the bombarding negative reviews of Devotion which might distort your impression of this game. [i]Many of the reviews are [b]irrational, unreasonable and heavily biased[/b] due to some contents included in the game.[/i] Despite some controversial “[url=https://www.spieltimes.com/original/xi-jinping-winnie-the-pooh-in-devotion-the-taiwanese-perspective-the-chinese-perspective-the-neutral-ground/]political issues [/url]” being raised, it is still a great masterpiece. [spoiler][strike]With these issues, it is even a greater masterpiece that ironically symbolizes the reality..[/strike][/spoiler]
[h1]Overview[/h1]
[b]Devotion is labeled as a horrific game, but it is actually a quality storytelling and interactive movie-game.[/b] If you are looking for a super scary game like outlast, this might not fit with your desire. Still, the team did a great job treating scary moments (you do need to have braveness and a strong heart). Although everything looks familiar to me, the cultural influence still makes me feel creepy. The story is based on Taiwanese society around 80s, depicting a family that was influenced by the social atmosphere and false religious beliefs. The story is well designed, suspenseful, tragic, but cozy and touching. I really enjoyed it. The open ending makes me feel complex and makes me be involved in figuring out what is really going on with the story.
[h1]In-Game Contents[/h1]
[b]The game has crazy amount of details and references, especially on the religious aspect.[/b] The graphics might not be as good as 3A title games, but it’s still very realistic like you’re in one of the old apartments. It’s pretty detailed that’s enough to create the environment and horrific atmosphere for storytelling, especially at this price point. The texture and the objects are realistic. The apartment looks very similar to the old houses that you will see in Taiwan. There are lots of references based on the contemporary background, such as the posters, TV show, time and dates, etc. The religious references are very detail as well, such as the rituals, idols, taboo. [b]The music is very good. It is [i]amazing beautiful[/i][/b], illustrated by the team and the award winning Mandarin Band to display the girl Mei Shin’s complex mind. 
[h1]Issues[/h1]
However, there are indeed somethings that makes me a little bit disappointed but will not affect the actual gaming experience. I would agree that there are some points where the climax has not been reached but already ends. In other words, I wish there would be more things. In regard to the amulet that most Chinese people felt insulting, it will not affect the gameplay if you don't figure out very carefully. [i]Those angry people are taking the game too seriously and led boycotting[/i]. The controversial amulet, although does sound like insulting the leader of China, [u][b]does not have direct meaning and you can have other interpretations.[/b][/u] Nonetheless, though claimed as mistakes, the game developers need to take some responsibilities (they did) for that because it does sound a bit like [u]personal insulting[/u] ([b]repeat: not humiliating[/b]). [b]Nonetheless, the dates and the numbers in the game, like stated at the beginning, are just truly coincident and fictional. For example, the date [b]Oct 7th 1987[/b] is actually moon-festival (families would gather) and has lunar eclipse, which is a really bad sign. The seventh day after death 10/7 is the first day the spirit will come back and revisit. The number "88" in Mandarin sound and mean exactly as "bye bye".[/b]

[h1]In-Depth Explainations[/h1]
*Spoiler Alert* Some explanations after gameplay if you do not understand (put pointer on black box):
[spoiler]
[olist]
[*]The game Devotion in Chinese is called “還願(huan2yuan4)”, and it is a pun. Ex.The last sentence of the song at the ending says “你還願(hai2yuan4)意嗎?” or [b]"Child’s Willingness" "孩願”[/b].
[*]There is a lot of cycling in the story, such as the ending loop, going to different doors with the same rooms, etc. Spirits might experience this if that he/she suicide or did something bad before death. This can continue for many many times until your sin is being cleansed. Most players believe you are experiencing the father’s cycling.
[*]1st Jumpscare: There's a saying that you should never look/turn back, or else you will lose "three flames of your soul" and your body will be controlled by the ghost/evil spirit.
[*]There's a scene where you repeatedly walk on the same aisle for many times, it is called "Ghost hitting the wall"; happens when the ghost is interfering your mind. 
[*]In Buddhism or Daoism, there are good idols and bad ones (or bad idols, possibly spirits pretending to be fake god). In this case, Cigu Guanyin is considered as a bad idol (*Cigu Guanyin is a fake idol made up by the dev. team, however, it is referred to the real god called "Zi Gu". The storybook basically tells a bit of ZiGu). You can recognize it by its sitting pose, the instruments that the idol is using, their finger pose, etc. Usually, when you pray and your wish comes true, you will need to redeem a vow to god, which is “devotion”. If you did not devote, then bad things will happen as a consequence. Cigu Guanyin probably wants Du to sacrifice. The mentor is a kind of prophet and probably uses Cigu Guanyin power to cheat on others. 
[*]The spiritual world operated through Guan Ling Rite called "觀落陰GuanLuoYin", a special way to communicate with the spirits (*not to sacrifice*). However, I have only heard of it. People would say you can communicate with you dead relatives using this method.
[*]Possible reasons that her daughter is sick: pressure from her parents or the apartment they lived in. The apartment, according to the poster leaks from the game dev, is a haunted house. There's a saying in Taiwan that if you live in a haunted house, you will lose your luck, becomes unhealthy, and other bad things might occur. 
 [/olist]
[/spoiler]

Again, as mentioned in the game: [b][i]the events, characters and organizations depicted in this game fortunatly are fictitious. Any similarity to actual persons, living or dead, locales or to actual historical events, is purely coincidental.[/i][b]
It is just a game.
If you like this review and would like to reveal the truth, please leave a thumbs-up, ty.

A short little horror experience in a rarely-explored setting. It is very much a walking simulator with only 1 section with a real fail state, so be warned those who don't like those.

A few of the decorations and other items had translations for what they were, but much much more was needed. I feel like I missed 70% of the context. There was also a few spelling mistakes and wrong word choices in the subtitles.

As far as horror goes, it wasn't very scary, and I really felt the game pulled its punch hard, cutting to credits instead of revealing the shock at the end. Implication is a very good tool in horror, but it was used too much in this game and robbed the ending of its impact.

It's still a good game, and I'd suggest it to others who would like a unique short, unique horror experience. The price point might be a bit high, given the length, but I felt it was worth it.

This game is absolutely brilliant, and a must-play for fans of games that utilize atmospheric, surreal setpieces and strong environmental storytelling. Although much of the imagery in this game is extremely obtuse and heavily couched in Taiwanese culture and religion, it tells a very down-to-earth story that many people will be able to relate to, and one that seems especially relevant today. The graphics are beautiful, the imagery is stunning and absolutely striking, the atmosphere is like nothing I've ever seen before, and it's much more than just another horror-flavored walking sim. There are multiple points throughout the game that utilize creative changes in gameplay that add even more layers of meaning and surrealism. There are also many creative and interesting puzzles that actually add depth to the story and themes. I think any fan of story-driven, psychological horror will be able to enjoy this.

Games are a form of escapism. Maybe, after a long hard day of work, you want to vent your anger. You can go and play a shooter or a slasher. It is relaxing. Maybe, you just want to chill and forget your troubles with some simulator or walk in a beautiful surreal scenery as a form of meditation. Maybe you want to feel something that you could never feel in real life in a safety of your appartment with racing games. Want to feel like a hero? RPG. Want to feel like smart general? Strategy. Want to stop feeling lonely? Dating sims. Want intellectual exercise? Puzzles. Want some adrenaline? Horror games.
Games are supposed to be fun. Not "funny", they don't have to be lighthearted. But fun. Something that will make you immerse yourself in world, different from your own and feel satisfied when you're done. And not feel like you're being forced into the real world against your will once more.

I know two languages - English and Russian. I can't read the political message the ingame posters carry. And so, I just played this game, not knowing about the shitstorm surrounding it. And I liked this game.
Detention was, hands down, my favorite horror from 2017, so I expected more of the same from Devotion. Some horror, but not as a main focus. Good, interesting, intriguing story, with a lot of symbolism. And in that regard, Devotion was a bit of a letdown. I still enjoyed it, but it was not as good as Detention.

The symbolism was a very prominent part of Detention. I still think that the way they presented [spoiler]the reading list[/spoiler] in that game was top-tier brilliance, one of the best moves in games that I've seen. Right from the start, Devotion presents you with [spoiler]"I" in it's title drawn as a cigarette, some characters that form lungs, your "protagonist" is a heavy smoker and your child has problems with breathing. You would think that that would play some role in the game, right? Wrong. They literally never came back to the theme of smoking.[/spoiler] That was a completely pointless misdirection. And all the other symbolism in the game was way too on the nose and easy to read. It was just... uninspired. I knew where the story was going after less than an hour of gameplay, and until the end, there were zero surprises.
Not to mention that the ending itself was awful. Abrupt, it didn't draw that final line I was hoping to see, instead just showing you some surreal visage and credits. It was awfully unsatisfying.
Other than that though, the game was alright. I liked the story, predictable as it was. The voice acting was great. The music was fantastic. The horror elements... kinda disappeard after the 1/3 of the game, with the rest of it being hardly scary at all. It's just an average game, that I enjoyed playing and will forget much faster than I could ever forget Detention.

However.

No matter what the message, you shouldn't use games as your political platform. As a Russian, I'm sick and tired of listening about "those evil Russians" in American media. And I'm equally tired of listening about how "we are so virtuous, unlike those horrible spoiled Americans" in Russian. I don't need to hear about Ukraine, I don't need to hear about England, about feminism, transgenders, homophobia, racism from either side - they are both equally annoying - I don't need this in my "free from this political bullshit" time. Time I use to escape and have fun. Time, I play videogames.
And while I personally have no attachment to the conflict this particular drama is about, I don't think that Devotion devs had the right to take that time of peace away from their players. It is dirty. It is despicable. It is... just a shame that what could just be a cute little story, a fun horror game, had to turn into... this.

Shame on you.

What I love about this game is how they managed ambition with practicality, the game doesn't try to outdo others like Layers of Fear, instead focusing on what they can do, they managed to create a short, simple story that isn't overly-ambitious to a point of exhaustion, which makes it on par for most of the genre-defining horror walking simulators. But it's more than that, for me it threads the line between Gone Home and Layers of Fear, while definitely a horror game, it doesn't bind itself to the genre, instead choosing to start from horror, but as you unravel the story, the monsters become human, morphing from horror to a family tragedy. Horror about what happened slowly turns into a father's search for truth.

Staying out of the political drama and review bombing by the Chinese, Devotion is an excellent, meticulously crafted horror title that is focused entirely on getting the story across to you through excellent visuals, freaky situations and a lot of flavor narrative.  It is a bit short, I completed it in under 3 hours, and it is more of a walking simulator than one might expect, but it is so well done that I don't regret my purchase at all.  There are a couple genuine moments of "gotcha" terror, but only one spot in the game that I encountered where you can actually die.  I enjoyed the story, I was satisfied with the plot and character development as it was presented to me, and it is a visually beautiful game.  I highly recommend it if you are of the sort of gamer usually turned off by the difficulty of a horror title but who likes some scares and a solid plot.

With Devotion Red Candle cements itself as one the best indie horror devs right now; able to build atmosphere without throwing screaming JPEGs at your face and able to intertwine it with well-written human stories.

Like Red Candle’s first game, Detention, Devotion is an adventure game but this time it’s a first person adventure game instead of being point and click. Puzzles tend to be logical and non-complex as well as doing a good job tying into what’s going on. There’s even a few gameplay shakeups too, like a third person puzzle platformer segment. There is one segment where you to have run away from a monster but it’s not that that bad, as long as you keep running you’re fine. Overall the gameplay is some solid adventure gaming.

The game’s atmosphere is fantastic, setting itself in a dream-like rundown apartment building. Most of the game’s horror is more subdued, i.e. noises in the dark, rooms shifting around as you leave them. There are a few jump scare moments, but there are rare and for the most part are earned. It also does cool aesthetic stuff like one segment where you control something akin to a museum diorama and another segment inside a storybook. There is even some FMV when it comes to stuff on the TV and apparently Red Candle got a live band and everything for the singing contest segments which is cool. The soundtrack is great too.

Just like Detention, Devotion has a strong narrative too.  Like Detention it’s also set in Taiwan, during the 80’s this time though. Unlike Detention, the historical context of Devotion isn’t as strong a focus though, instead delving more into the personal lives of its characters. Said characters being a  small family and their struggles, one major focus being how the father and his refusal to swallow his pride and do what’s best for his family leads him down a destructive road into joining a cult that jeopardizes his family. Devotion does a good job with environmental storytelling to get some of the narrative across. Red Candle’s touch hasn’t been lost at all when it comes to human stories well. My only minor nitpick is the ending is a little too abrupt but that’s fine and it fits there really isn’t any kind of denouement.

Finally if you’re wondering about the review bomb it’s a bunch of Chinese trolls getting real mad about an easter egg calling Xi Jinping Winnie the Pooh. The dangers of fanatical cult-like devotion, it’s like the whole theme of this game and even part of Detention’s or something. You can’t make up this kind of irony, folks.

Devotion is a great horror adventure game and along with RE2make should definitely be powerful contenders for upcoming GOTY lists.

So, I have completed this game in three hours and they were beautiful. 
At first, this is not a horror game. I mean, there are some screamers and spooky moments, but it is not a horror. There is no action gameplay like Alien: Isolation (except for one moment), there's only a narrative. It is just a dark story: like Edith Finch, but scary. 
The best part of the game is good, great location design. There aren't much video games which have so much of this "room art", so this game is notable. This is one of the main features of the game, no doubt, and it's a shame that I can tell not too much about it because it's worth seeing.
The plot is... great too, but it's hard to explain what developers wanted to tell to us. There is only one ending that, sorry for a small spoiler, can be described as [spoiler]happy[/spoiler], but I can't figure out what was the main idea of the game. Seems like it is one plot about pretty much everything to think about. 
So, I recommend this game. It is just a good attraction for one evening.

I thought this game was excellent (though I still haven't played Detention). I've played just about every horror game I could get my grimy claws on for at least a decade, and Devotion found its way on my list fairly quickly. I'm not Taiwanese, but I have taken Mandarin classes with Taiwanese teachers, and I learned enough over the years to pick out some of the cultural aspects the horror itself was rooted in. Obviously, I missed quite a bit, but I knew enough for my experience to be enhanced. That's not to say that if you don't know anything about Taiwanese culture - and, yes, I would argue it's distinct from mainland Chinese culture - you won't enjoy  the game. 

It's got no combat and no hiding from spooky monsters; gameplay is story-driven with some light puzzles. The scares are derived from atmosphere and from the story, itself, rather than jumpscares and gore. If that appeals to you, and you're not angry at the thought of Taiwan's independence from mainland China, then this game is for you!

Prior to purchase, I didn't know about the director's politics, but now that I know? I might buy copies for people who would enjoy this. My teachers were discouraged from saying they were Taiwanese, instead encouraged to say they're Chinese and to foster identity with a country that has moved in on their country and culture, just as the mainland moved in on Hong Kong and other Cantonese speaking areas, to the point where teenagers are abandoning the language of their culture and history in favour of Mandarin. 

So, in honour of my teachers: 你們是臺灣人.

For those who think that the easter egg is a harmless joke, I know it is hard for you to understand why many Chinese (as I am one) feel completely the opposite. Let me try to explain it.

I am not sure how bad it will be if some game has an easter egg praising the 911 or any campus massacre as glorious incidents, or hide words like "nigger" all over the game and ACTUALLY mean to promote hatred towards any racial group. Are they illegal? Probably not. U.S. is a nation that protects free speech. But those easter eggs will hurt the feeling of a lot of American, I believe. 

As a Chinese, I might feel that these hatred easter eggs I made up are only about "political correctness" and some U.S. people are overreacting. But I do know that they cares about political correctness, so I will gently respect their opinions, and will never include those content if I am the game producer. 

Looking back at the game. No body knows better than Chinese people that politics is very sensitive in China (both mainland and Taiwan). I don't like any propaganda shit-talking Taiwan, and at the same time I hope people can respect my choice to respect my country.

If you think the easter egg is hidden by some random developer that's unrelated to the RedCandleGames, I also hope that is the case. But as it turns out that there are many similar metaphors only obvious after we see the one text evidence (one that explicitly writes Xi's name). When it comes to metaphor, it is hard to argue what is their intention. But one text evidence is enough to blow everything up because it is just too sensitive a topic.

Hope this helps you understand how Chinese people feel, or you feel the same.

Previous Comment:

Chinese political cultists are review bombing the game because it dares make fun of Supreme God-Emperor For Life Xi-nny the Pooh. I'll write a proper review when I complete the game, but for the time being I'm gonna help against the bombing. 

So far the game is holding up on many quality levels, and the plot is intriguing me.

Actual Review:

So this is a Layers of Fear style narrative-driven horror game with some "connect the dots" style puzzles where you have to "earn" an item from one area, to use in another, or gain a clue from one item that then helps you solve something in another.

Each chapter has its own style to help freshen things up, and the story is rich and tragic. The graphics are certainly passable for the most part, in some areas looking photo-real and others not so much.

It has a good share of spooks and scares, some cliché, others not so much, either way I was thrilled playing this game.

It is entirely linear, there are no divergent paths or additional endings, which I feel like, perhaps it could have done? The story definitely needs a bit of thinking to unravel, and after completing it, I'm unsure what to conclude.

It would be nice to have an FOV slider (as I will say in every first person game that doesn't have one...) but it didn't bother me so much that I couldn't play. I just have a large screen and have to sit quite close to it due to my living arrangements, so it can be uncomfortable with such a restrictive FOV.

Overall, if you like Layers of Fear and want another spooky, trippily delivered story to get in to, Devotion is a good one to experience, though it is quite short, with no replay value.

Absolutely beautiful game, incredibly disturbing and incredibly beautiful. You might think from the intro that you're in for a typical horror movie scarefest, but what you're actually in for is a deeply contemplative, heartbreaking story about a family in 1980s Taiwan. 

And Taiwanese this game is. They nailed the look and the atmosphere, from the wall tiles used in the bathroom to the general decor and state of disrepair of the apartment complex, everything is spot-on. 

Regarding the review bombing:

- There is no character named Lu Gongmin in the game. There's not really even a cult leader; the only character you meet who is connected to the cult is named Mentor Heuh/He Laoshi. I don't know where this is coming from unless I missed it in one of the game's news clippings.
- There isn't any explicit or even really implicit anti-CCP or anti-mainlander sentiment in the game.
- The thing about Xi Jinping being depicted as a child attacker in the game is not true. I don't know where that comes from.

Play this game. It's one of the best walking simulators ever made, and a brilliant piece of Taiwanese history perfectly encapsulated.

I had ZERO expectations & in fact owned this game for years, never giving it a chance or moment of my time.  The FO fans had convinced me this was garbage and the worst Fallout experience you could possibly have.  FO fans clearly expressed after New Vegas, the series and everything connected to it is trash.

So I log in to FO76 and feel a bit overwhelmed with all the options & systems...few weeks later of running with friends, this game is actually amazing in many ways.  Despite not being on an Unreal engine, the atmosphere feels good.  Weather effects, storms & desolation all feels good.  You can do tons of different things I have NEVER seen combined into a survival shooter sandbox.

you can build a base, setup powered 'circuits', tons of animated furnishings, earn ATOMS via questing, crafting, groups events.  Season pass does push to subscribe, BUT there are lots of FREE things to be obtained.

All the 'fans' that hate on this game, I do get it - It's not New Vegas, there will never be another New Vegas!  However, FO76 is a fun game that gives me stalker + H1Z1 vibes.  Setting up your loot in a shop is a big part of the base-building.

Unlike ESO there are stakes and you can get killed in the overworld if you're not careful.  As for events, they are not instanced in many cases, allowing you to call in artillery strikes from your base and other strange things.

The build options, loot tables, vendors, quests & landscape have a lot to offer without paying for a subscription.  Just grabbing a burger combo at Wendy's these days costs $15 to $20 a visit, so if you do sub, they hand you tons of in-game currency & QoL = that is not required to enjoy the game, but does feel generous compared to ESO & other games of the genre.

Good game that got a lot of well-deserved cr@p for a garbage release, but is now a lot of fun with tons of ways to enjoy it.  Worth a look for sure!  I grabbed it on-sale for $7 and it's a ridiculous amount of content for that price or even at $50.

If you're looking for an MMO version of Fallout, this is likely going to satisfy that need. If you're looking for a Fallout Experience with optional multiplayer, you're likely not going to find it here. FO76 takes many of the most entertaining aspects of Fallout 4 and hides them behind unlockables/paywalls. I completely understand why some would appreciate the changes to the leveling, crafting, and base-building aspects of Fallout 4, but they really slowed the game down for me. 
This would have been better as a DLC for FO4.

My experience with Fallout 76: (nVidia 5090, AMD9950X3D, 192GB RAM)
1st boot: Horrible stuttering. FPS showed to be 90-109, but it was absolutely unbearable to watch. GPU utilization was around 20-30%, CPU around 12%.
2nd boot: The stuttering disappeared magically, GPU utilization jumped to 80%, CPU hangs around 12-18%. Networks issue(?) makes character stuck on it's tracks from to time. Preventing movement. After few seconds the character is able to move again normally.
3rd boot: Disabled the VPN, in case it could have cause the possible network issues. Didn't help. Still got stuck on my tracks , usually after looting something and after I finally reached The Wayward and went inside, character just stood there, unable to move in any direction. I quiet the game after a minute of standing. So I guess this is it. Good bye Fallout 76, you never became anything.

Other than those issues, I must say I do not understand this game. Because as a base game concept, it's great. Fallout with friends! But, it's in this stupid, greedy, malicious live service model. This could have been a great game, if it had been just Fallout with co-op. But no, Bethesda had to go greedy (again) and make dumdum decisions. Like, really? How do you F things up with the concept that could have been such a great thing. "Single player game with an option to play with friends."

On a positive side, at least it's rather pretty - for a Bethesda game. And it has gone better, since the last time I tested it; gun play feels more precise, at least.
It's just still annoying to play because of technical issues, base building mechanics (would have loved to make a permanent base anywhere I want, but because of the live service, always online, model, not a possibility).
No, just no.

Honestly don't know why people hated on this. The only downside is that you can't be a complete psychopath and kill everything that breathes and the dialogue can feel stale at times but otherwise pretty good game.

A really fun Fallout game these days after the rough start. Still has its flaws here and there, but very much enjoying puttering about mostly solo building my camp and shelter and trying to get the best loot possible for my build.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
If you’re looking for an objective review of Fallout 76 from a person who was raised on Fallout 1 & 2 - this is an ok game where you can have fun. After years of improvement I can finally recommend playing it and even buying Fallout 1st (yep). And if you’re looking for something that could change your view, take a look on the deep dive.


[h1]-Deep Dive-[/h1]

Is the hate that Fallout 76 receives justified? Yes.
Is the game a letdown for longtime Fallout fans? Partially.
Is it worth hating, blaming Bethesda for ruining the franchise and angrily accusing Todd of total destruction of a game universe we love? Well, I can’t believe I finally can say - Hell no.

[u]The Devs[/u]
Fallout 76 nowadays is a 7/10 game. The devs truly improved it, fixed lots of annoying and game breaking bugs. They’ve rebalanced the game to the point it’s actually enjoyable to play it the way you want. The unmentionable amount of bugs, glitches and crashes are no longer there and it’s thanks to the devs and great community build throughout all those years. The rebalance is there, the enjoyment is there, and most importantly, the sheer fun of playing a Fallout game can be found there. There is a catch though.

[u]The Universe[/u]
If you think that Fallout 76 is ruining the franchise - I don’t blame you. For years I thought the same and was disappointed for Bethesda allowing it. Retcons, playground approach, pastel colors, silly outfits and monetisation were annoying me for years. I truly hated Bethesda until I started to understand why.
This is not Obsidian’s dirty Post-Post-Apocalypse - a commentary of how people will always find a way to rage war and always find a cause for it. This is Bethesda’s Fallout, still the same kind of apocalypse, still the same universe, but their commentary focuses more on grotesque American Dream, consumerism and environmental storytelling. Is it disappointing it’s not the same approach? Of course it is. But is it bad that the company who took over a great franchise, want to improve on it approaching it differently, yet carefully (to some degree)? Nope.

[u]The Fallout[/u]
The apocalypse is there. The struggle to meet ends meet is there. The gritty, dirty, despicable world is there. So why myself and thousand fans are angry with Beth for “ruining the franchise”? Simple answer is that we’re either in a particular information bubble or we just feel hurt and don’t want to let go out of fear we might like it, no matter what. Everything we know and love from previous Fallouts is actually there. Factions who think their approach is best - check. Plot showing ruthlessness and insanity of pre-war corporations - check. Grotesque danger lurking in the wasteland - check. The path from radroach smasher to Supermutant eradicator- check. It’s still Fallout in its core. What we don’t accept is Bethesda’s take on it. 

[u]The Disagreement[/u]
We don’t accept the ridiculousness of the wasteland, the improvements on some plot holes, the ruining of our nostalgia. We’re basically homesick but furious that our home have been modernized. We want good old Fallout no matter what, knowing deep down it’s not possible in XXIst century. Bethesda sacrifices some parts of the franchise to basically balance the profits, old fans satisfaction and new players enjoyment. It’s not perfect but it’s either this, franchise abandonment or full focus on mainstream audience. Considering that, we’re in a pretty comfortable place.

[u]The Details[/u]
Remember the Morningstar and Kokoweef mines with their mine scrips from Fallout 2? It’s an actual side currency in 76.
G.E.C.K. technology? It’s now an actual device usable by vault dwellers as C.A.M.P.
Tragic the Garnering card game, which apparently “isn’t just a game” and “changes a person’s” life”? Level-up perk cards.
ZAX supercomputer? Present in Vault 51.
Nicknaming the character on boxing ring? Prefixes and suffixes.
Fallout 3 information about vault purposes scattered in terminals? Vault 76 purpose of studying the wasteland is mentioned on Fallout 3 Citadel terminal.
Mojave Express Dropboxes? Camp stash.
Those are all references to previous games. It’s actually impressive that they’ve been adapted as a mechanic or implemented effortlessly in this game.

[u]The Monetisation[/u]
Is Fallout 1st game breaking? Absolutely fucking not. Is it helpful? Of course. Is it worth it? It depends. You may pay $15 for WoW subscription which has immense amounts of content. Should you be ostracised? You’re paying for something which brings you fun and lets you enjoy a product with friends/similarily passionate people, that’s no waste of money. Fallout 76 doesn’t have the same amount of content, yet it’s the franchise you enjoy. 1st gives you advantage and is optional. You won’t be worse without it and you most certainly won’t be better with it. It’s a bottomless stash, fast travel tent and value in atoms spent in Atomic Shop. Sure you can buy resource generators or items giving you advantage in a way that you don’t have to search for items in the wasteland. You can also buy cosmetics and camp items. Nonetheless, it won’t give you an edge over other players because there is no competition, no chasing leaderboards. You pay only for stuff you want to see more often or stuff that helps you with chore-like item hoarding. It’s not necessary, it’s got good value in in Atomic Shop currency and just makes the game a tad more comfortable. That’s it.

[u]The Self-hatred[/u]
There’s lots of things I didn’t mention intentionally. Bugs, illusion of choice, legendary weapons, battle pass. I didn’t mention them because they either don’t influence my enjoyment at all or just on a minimal scale. I often heard “why are you playing this again, you said it’s shit”. Truth is, the game was rigged from the start. The default hate was comfortable, but it’s still a product with Fallout in its name. I’m a die hard Fallout fan and wanted to understand what makes me so mad about this product. I’m glad I did because the deep dive proved me wrong. I enjoy it because it’s Fallout, and I hated it because I felt let down like somebody dissected my favourite franchise and taxidermised it by Chuck Testa*. It wasn’t. It was modernized with care.

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
This wall of text is from a long time fan of the franchise, a person who put some effort to understand why, and let go of the mainstream hate. You don’t have to agree with my opinion, hell, you can continue hating it. Just make sure you hate it for the good reasons and not just simple - OPINIONS. OPINIONS NEVER CHANGES.
7/10, will play it, will come back to it periodically, will look forward to future improvements.


[i]*Chuck Testa does not taxidermise favourite franchises.[/i]

Fallout 76 is severely overhated. I get that it had a bad launch but I feel people just make fun of the game now because of the state of it's launch just being a meme. Yes it was buggy, yes it was boring and yes it was extremely rushed but most of (not all) all these problems are long gone. Fallout 76 as of November 2025 when I write this review is a genuinely fun and interesting game that expands upon the gameplay mechanics of Fallout 4. It's so visually mesmerizing to see fallout in a somewhat modern graphical fidelity. Fallout 76 has a very interesting story too. Everybody who makes the same foolish stance "fAllOuT 76 hAs nO sToRy bRo" suffers from severe mental retardation because when I played the game and went through all the Responder holotapes and slowly uncovered what really happened to them, what happened to the Brotherhood of Steel, what happened to the enclave, i genuinely felt a somber feeling witnessing it for the first time. Fallout 76 has so much interesting lore inside of it that is expanded upon. Im not going to talk about it too much but basically you find out more about the foundation of the brotherhood, more about the Enclave's 'purity' goal, but most importantly you actually get to feel resentment towards the first hand witnesses of the Great War. You get to see how people reminisce about their time living as a human before the war (25 years ago), with their families, friends, all gone. How all of humanities greatest achievments amounted to nothing. Just large irradiated craters in the dirt.  (minor spoiler alert) Me personally the most interesting thing I found in the game was when the Non-Enclave members of the United States Cabinet arrived at the Whitesprings bunker, a place with the intention to safeguard all the important government officials away from the bombs the Enclave executed every last one. Even though they weren't irradiated, even though they were active United States Secretaries and various other important figures they were still viewed as 'muties' or 'unpure'. Anyways just to conclude, please please please don't listen to the incels and be consumed by this overarching shroud of negativity directed towards this game for no apparent reason. The game is really good 99/100 must recommend!!!

Hi Bethesda team,

I’ve been playing Fallout since I was young — it’s more than just a game to me, it’s part of my memories. Fallout 76 has a world I really love, especially the building and exploration parts.

I just want to share this sincerely: I understand how much effort and passion your team puts into this game. I truly appreciate all the hard work from the developers and writers — it’s not easy to keep a live game running and improving.

Still, I hope you can take another look at the balance between the Fallout 1st membership and Atom Store prices. I don’t mind spending money to support the game, but right now, some prices feel a bit too high for what players receive. Features like the Scrap Box or larger storage being behind a paywall can make some of us feel limited.

Please don’t take this as a complaint — it’s just honest feedback from someone who really loves Fallout and wants it to keep growing. I hope one day the game’s support options can feel more rewarding and fair for everyone.

Thank you again for everything you’ve done for Fallout 76. Even with its flaws, it’s still one of the games closest to my heart.

— A player who still loves this world ❤️

Me: [i]"I think I'm done. With the game. Like for forever."[/i]
My brother: [i]"Yeah, let's stop."[/i]

When we stopped playing the game in 2023, [b]Fallout 76[/b] had received countless patches, content drops, questlines, side characters and [i]battle passes[/i].
The game had become a hodgepodge of varying quality in almost all aspects and more and more you could see the seams of a game that was becoming rapidly incoherent with every new update.

Yes, when the game released it was not done.
It had a half-baked battle royale mode stacked on top, because that was "the big thing" at the time, before it was patched out at some point, early in its live service life.
Back then there was not a single living friendly npc in the game, despite a ton of holotapes, journal entries and an insane amount of world building. No living quest givers existed for quite a while in [b]76[/b] and that was a crazy break from what Fallout had been up to that point.
But that didn't matter to my brother and I!
We could finally play Fallout together and despite how basic our experience was compared to earlier games in the series, we still spent countless hours devouring every little thing we could find.

Here's the thing, [b]Fallout 76[/b]'s original, version 1.0, game package was designed around the limitation it still had back then. There were lore reasons why the map was devoid of friendly human life. It made sense. It wasn't deus ex machina nonsene. It kept making sense as you progressed through the varying areas and interesting locales. Kept making sense with every new little tidbit of information or world building.
But with every new live service update that changed.
It lost part of its original appeal. Or idea.
That original experience had been bulldozed over countless times when we were still playing the game and that bulldozer has not stopped once, as [b]76[/b] keeps being a very lucrative game for Bethesda, as they keep re-releasing the same two games for all eternity.

[b]Fallout 76[/b]'s world doesn't make sense anymore.
But it also can't remove any of the new things to allow you to witness that original experience. And in the same vein, it also can't remove what was originally there, because everything is stacked on top of that.

I loved that original [b]Fallout 76[/b].
I've made so many memories in its first or so year, that I'll probably never remember all of them.

Review: Fallout 76 (Wastelanders Update)

I’ve been playing Fallout 76 for a while now, and it really reminds me of the classic Fallout experience — in the best possible way. With the Wastelanders Update, the game finally became a full, proper Fallout title.

The return of real NPCs, dialogue choices, and meaningful factions brought back the heart of what makes Fallout special. Quests feel personal again, decisions matter, and Appalachia now feels alive and worth exploring.

On Steam, performance is stable, and the combination of the C.A.M.P. system, Legendary Perks, and regular events offers plenty to do without feeling like a grind. The world looks great, the atmosphere is strong, and there’s always something new to discover.

What surprised me most is the community — genuinely friendly and helpful players, which is rare in online games.

Verdict: Fallout 76 has finally become what it was always meant to be — a true Fallout experience with multiplayer elements. If you enjoy the series, it’s absolutely worth jumping back in.

⭐ Rating: 8 / 10 – Recommended, especially since Wastelanders.


Review Update: Fallout 76 – Brotherhood of Steel (Steel Dawn / Steel Reign)

The Brotherhood of Steel expansions turned Fallout 76 into something truly close to the single-player Fallout feeling many players had been missing. With Steel Dawn and Steel Reign, Bethesda added a strong narrative backbone — full of moral choices, solid writing, and that familiar Brotherhood tension between idealism and control.

The quests are well-paced, the voice acting fits the faction perfectly, and new locations like Fort Atlas feel authentic within Appalachia’s world. Equipment upgrades, new weapons, and armor sets make progression satisfying without breaking balance.

Performance and stability continue to improve, and the Brotherhood story adds a sense of purpose to the late game. It finally feels like your character has a reason to keep exploring beyond daily events.

Verdict: A great addition that deepens Fallout 76’s lore and atmosphere. Whether you side with or against the Brotherhood, this DLC gives the game the narrative depth it always deserved.

⭐ Rating: 8.5 / 10 – Recommended for anyone who enjoys Fallout’s classic factions and moral gray

I felt more engaged writing this review than I did in ~15 hours of giving this game a chance. 

The word "slop" is thrown around a lot these days, but Fallout 76 is the very definition of inoffensive, sterile, commercial slop. It's like going home, and finding out your favourite spot is now a Starbucks.

It's a treadmill of banal, meaningless content that just serves to pass time. You're not being challenged. You're not even thinking. Nothing is a threat, everything is level scaled. I never once died to an enemy. I rarely even had to heal. You fight enemies, to make number go up. You pick up litter, to build stuff, to make number go up. It's a pointless cyclical ritual.

It's so diluted it's insulting. Things that were unlocked by default in Fallout 4, in crafting and settlement building, are now chopped off and thrown into loot tables for you to (very slowly) find. Everything is a grind, everything is tedious. It feels like that's the entire point of the game, too. 

It's an incredibly static and lifeless game. Everything happened before you got there. All of the stories I found, were the same flavour of "my boss is a dick" that was tired back in Fallout 3. It's uninteresting. Why should I care? These people are all dead and the world ended. Throw me into a story that's actively happening. Let me shape it. That's Fallout.

76 is a terrible multiplayer game, on top of all this. You don't share quests, so everyone is playing their own game, just in a shared space. If you see other people, most of the time you just ignore them. They can't hurt you, or really help you, outside of just dropping you a bunch of free items you really don't need anyway.

I could go on, but this game doesn't deserve it. It's dull, tedious, and soulless. You could pick up 2-3 indie games for this price that were made by people with passion and heart, that would be a way better use of your limited time on this Earth.

If you really need to kill time this bad, idk man learn a skill. Get an instrument.

🇬🇧 Fallout 76 – Enclave Forever. Glory to the Old World.

I started playing Fallout 76 recently, and I’ll be honest — I didn’t expect to enjoy it this much. The game still captures that unique Fallout feeling: the atmosphere, the music, the weird NPCs, the silence of the wasteland — it all feels right.

I love building my CAMP and exploring every corner of Appalachia. The new Ghoul Update is amazing — becoming a ghoul adds a fresh layer of immersion. When I do faction quests, I even hide my identity… it just feels right for the character.

Still, Fallout 76 isn’t perfect. PvP is basically dead, and even though it’s an MMORPG, all quests are solo only. It’s disappointing when I play with friends — we pick the same quest, but the game sends us into separate solo instances. If I wanted to do every mission alone, I’d just play single-player Fallout.

But even with all its flaws, there’s something special here. The world feels alive, and the community is one of the friendliest I’ve ever seen in an online game.

If you love Fallout and want to experience its world with others — even if it’s not a perfect MMO — Fallout 76 is still worth every hour.

⭐ 8/10 – Enclave forever. Glory to the Old World.

🇬🇷 Fallout 76 – Enclave για πάντα. Δόξα στον Παλαιό Κόσμο.

Ξεκίνησα να παίζω πρόσφατα το Fallout 76 και ειλικρινά δεν περίμενα να μου αρέσει τόσο. Το παιχνίδι κρατάει ακόμα αυτό το μοναδικό Fallout συναίσθημα: η ατμόσφαιρα, η μουσική, οι παράξενοι NPCs, η σιωπή της ερημιάς — όλα είναι στη θέση τους.

Λατρεύω να χτίζω το CAMP μου και να εξερευνώ κάθε γωνιά της Appalachia. Το νέο Ghoul Update είναι εξαιρετικό — το να γίνεσαι ghoul δίνει άλλη αίσθηση στον ρόλο. Όταν κάνω αποστολές με φατρίες, κρύβω την ταυτότητά μου… γιατί έτσι ταιριάζει στον χαρακτήρα μου.

Όμως το Fallout 76 δεν είναι τέλειο. Το PvP είναι ουσιαστικά νεκρό, και παρότι θεωρείται MMORPG, όλες οι αποστολές είναι μόνο για solo. Είναι απογοητευτικό να ξεκινάς την ίδια αποστολή με έναν φίλο και να σας στέλνει σε ξεχωριστά instances. Αν ήθελα να τα κάνω όλα μόνος, θα έπαιζα ένα single-player Fallout.

Παρά τα ελαττώματά του όμως, έχει κάτι ξεχωριστό. Ο κόσμος του μοιάζει ζωντανός και η κοινότητα είναι από τις πιο φιλικές που έχω δει σε online παιχνίδι.

Αν αγαπάς το Fallout και θέλεις να ζήσεις την εμπειρία του με άλλους, ακόμα κι αν δεν είναι το τέλειο MMO — το Fallout 76 αξίζει κάθε ώρα.

⭐ 8/10 – Enclave forever. Glory to the Old World.

I bought it on launch for the Xbox. Let me tell you - it was the biggest flop ever.
I then bought it back in 2021, I think, for PC. It was still... quite the sad existence.

And now? Now it's, in my opinion, one of the greatest Fallout games ever. The community is friendly, the story is also... quite nice. And there are multiple different events happening at the same time. 
To summarize; A 8/10. They released a car wreck, and built that wreck into a sports car.
I like this game because the community has grown. There is a grand span of amazing players willing to help, and have a great time.

Game still really, really horrible to play on PC.
The framerate is capped, but with some strange interpolation that makes mouse aim feel floaty and brought on motion sickness within an hours play. This can be resolved by editing the settings .ini file, but then all movement input stops randomly due to the framerate being too high...
What a mess. The simple, easy to use menus and build system from fallout 4 are gone, replaced with a miserable, confusing and inconsistent UI experience. Then there's the paywalls - no private games unless you fork over cash. *Wonderful*.
On the plus side, the quests are interesting (even though the tutorial is shockingly bad) and the new perk/level up system is different and refreshingly good. Enemy design is at least interesting, and combat is fun (at least at early levels). The dynamic events are a great touch, and the huge map is packed with details.
Shame it's basically unplayable out of the box.

Although I'm a quite new player and haven't (yet) faced the lowest or the highest points of the game I can confidently say that I really enjoy Fallout 76.

PROS:
+ Events are fun Fallout style chaos
+ The community is really friendly
+ PVP has been made possible but not "default"
+ You get to build and decorate your C.A.M.P
+ You can buy instruments and start the bad you have dreamed of since being a teenager
+ Hey, it's a damn MMORPG Fallout!

CONS:
- The default controls are worse than in any other game (you will get used to them)
- Although the game receives bug fixes it can still be buggy, and often crash when you launch it if you open it "too fast"
- The main story is really boring (but the side quests and events compensate that)
- You can have almost any pet (which is +) but they won't be able to follow you :(

...just remember to have enough time to play, this game will get you hooked!

So this was a kind of a weird experience to me. And please, I've only played it for a few hours so correct me if I'm wrong:
You can build a house and there's a glorious wide assortment of stuff to decorate your house with. All cool. BUT! Your house is only visible when you're in the game - and it seems if you place the house somewhere close to where another player has placed theirs, and you two are in the game at the same time, your house is just... gone if the other player logged on before you (I assume this is the logical order of things). This happened to me, I had a message telling me it could no longer place my home base, so I was given a second location "for free"... Well, hooray for that... :/

Also - and again, I am a noob in the game - but it seems to me that this is sort of a "single player game with other players", in that missions were tied to your character, there's no cooperative team missions, no tasks that we as a team do together. So it's kind of a weird mix of classic Fallout and a multiplayer game.

All in all I would not directly NOT recommend this game - it's just Steam that's limited to either YAY or NAY, but don't expect the most polished MP game out there, is what I'm saying. It's kind of an oddball of a mix of genres on top of a house building system that really is quite questionable when you risk losing it all unless you place it somewhere noone else would think of building their home.

I played this when it first came out - and was the greatest fun - did all the expansions up to and including Skyline. Then had a break from the game and came back recently ( Oct 2025) after hearing that there was a new expansion due . What a  major disappointment!!!! So, i made a new character ( thinking it had been awhile ) BUT now everything levels with you , so your first job to Morgan town and instead of being mob by 20+ lvl 5s - its 20+ lvl 19s my level - me my single shot pipe pistol and my crappy machete - DEAD - again - and so it went on, massively tedious and frustrating given that weapons lvl only rise every 10 lvls.  So following the Overseers mission was just the same over and over - Hunterville a town filled with super Mutants with missile launcher & minigun - used to be lvl 16s now they are all lvl 50s and over powered at that , sneak hide, shoot, die - 1 shotted. Pushed on managed to join the Enclave and build some  0-x1 power armor - smiling!!!! - until a regular scorchbeast came along and melted in within 1.30 mins, no amount of pumping simpacks could save me- Damn long walk back to pick up that little paper bag with all my dropped crap in it. Now 120 and the lvl 100 Snagglygasters and Toxic larrys punish me to within an inch of my life - again way over powered as i used to belt them dead with my ALL RISE no problem - and so it goes on everything is lvl 100 and nothing is fun. And i can see by my little achievements sticker i am not the only one feeling this way - basic ones show only 13,9% , 17% 14% of player reach them - tiny % - Bethesda is obviously are not interested in new players - so dont waste your money here. I read tons of new guides , and all they talk about is Legendary Mods (which need lots of time to get together to buy) and the new weapons that you can only get plans with Bullion - but you need to be able to survive the story - which is single player.  So sad - am a total Fallout fans with over 2000 hours on Fallout 4 - they have turned a fun game ( even for solo players) into a tedious grind with impossible goals - like yeah i will just pull this set of T65 out of my arse- because it only took me 2 years to get the first set - i am sure that Scorchbeast will just wait over there for me - or the 30+ Lvl 100 mole miners now lurking at Welsch station - save your money and sanity new players -  look somewhere else

Played this game since it came out, I've been through all sorts of the issues this game has had. It's honestly gotten pretty good, and they keep adding to it...
But last season, they added something that's been pretty much setting my PC on fire. Loading into the game, loading into a map, approaching an area... My PC has never stuttered so bad before. Sometimes it even causes the monitor i'm playing it on to just gives up and go full digital static.

Honestly the hours on my account does say that I enjoyed my time in this game. But I was just suddenly hit with massive performance issues that I didn't have before. I've tried various gfx drivers, no difference. Everything else on my PC works fine. So i'm just figurin' it was a game patch that broke something.

Edit: It says I received this product for free... I did not... I purchased this day 1. I even left the check box saying "If you received this product for free" unchecked...

I've been trying to give this game another try for a while, but there's no way. In the two times I've had two different PC configurations, this game has always given me problems. The classic problems of poor optimization; such as shuttering and frame drops. Before, I had a PC with a Ryzen 2600X, RX 570 GB and 16 GB of RAM. Now AMD Ryzen 7 5800X, AMD RX 6600 8 GB and 16 GB of RAM. Well, not much has changed. Obviously, I've tried solutions, but in the end, none of them seem to definitively solve the problems (or alleviate them). I play Cyberpunk 2077 on high details at 1080p, 144hertz without any problems. I played the same thing again on Death Stranding 1 on high details, 1080p, without any problems. This is clearly a Fallout 76 problem. Too bad, it would have interesting things to offer. But Bethesda is that clown company that, instead of fixing the problems, just continues to add new content to the already heavy game in its 100 GB of storage. The same Bethesda that re-released the same old game from 2015 called Fallout 4. Fallout New Vegas Remake or Remastered PLS

It's pretty insane to be writing this just 2 hours in. I bought this on an 80% sale assuming, "It's been years, surely it's fixed by now, right?"

[b]Wrong.[/b]

This game is a complete and utter technical and visual disaster.
You don't even NEED to be a *Fallout* fan to hate this garbage. You just need to be someone who enjoys framerates that exist above "slideshow" and graphics that don't look like they're actively disintegrating.

[b]PROS:[/b]

* [b]The Nicest Community:[/b] Honest to God, I'm shocked by how nice and helpful the community is. By far the nicest MMORPG community I've ever met. (And not the creepy "Herbert the Pervert" kind like in *Final Fantasy XIV*). High-level players seem to just hand out gear to new players.
* [b]The Sale Price:[/b] At least I only wasted a few bucks and not the full $60.

[b]CONS:[/b]

* [b]PERFORMANCE DISASTER:[/b] This is the #1 reason. I'm on a 9800 X3D, an RTX 5090, 128GB of RAM and a Gen 4 NVMe SSD. My PC is NOT the problem. This game is.

    The framerate is an unstable, vomit-inducing mess. It shows 160 highs and 32 lows and *never* once felt smooth except when I entered instanced interiors. It constantly feels like it's running at 25 FPS regardless of what the counter says.

https://i.imgur.com/Ga79QEE.png

* [b]IT LOOKS LIKE ASS:[/b] The performance isn't just bad; the game is hideous.
    * [b]Abysmal LoD:[/b] You can watch entire buildings and mountains pop into existence 40 feet in front of you.
    * [b]Broken Shadows:[/b] There is weird distracting shadow checkerboxing on almost every surface especially noticeable on brightly colored buildings.
    * [b]Constant Pop-in:[/b] Rocks, forests and junk just appear out of thin air as you walk. It's pretty immersion-breaking.

https://i.imgur.com/cfYpDo7.jpeg

This looks way worse than Fallout 4. Honestly it looks even worse than New Vegas in a lot of regards. Keep in mind that this garbage came out during the same year as Marvel's Spider-Man, God of War, Detroit: Become Human, etc.

* [b]GAME-BREAKING JANK:[/b] In just two hours, I've seen constant AI desync, AI teleporting to me, AI turning invisible, and AI getting stuck on geometry like stairs or a house's wall.

It feels like a pre-alpha from 2015 and not a "fixed" game from 2025.

[b]THE FALLOUT 1ST "FIX" IS A LIE:[/b]
I even bought one month of Fallout 1st. I figured, "Okay, maybe the public servers are just dying from the *Fallout* TV show popularity?"

[b]Yeah, nevermind. It runs exactly the same.[/b]

The core game engine is just a 7-year-old turd. Paying Bethesda a monthly fee doesn't fix the optimization, it doesn't fix the abysmal graphics, and it doesn't fix the broken AI. It just gives you a magic junk box inside a game that runs like one.

[b]RATINGS:[/b] 3/10

[b]BOTTOM LINE:[/b]
My PC can run a space rocket to the moon. It cannot, apparently, get a stable framerate or load assets correctly in this 2018 game.

I genuinely don't understand how people can lower their standards enough to tolerate this level of jank and visual garbage long enough to get to level 600+. The only explanation is that the community is just that good. And they did genuinely give me great vibes.

It's the same old Bethesda story for the last 10 years: a technically garbage game that is uniquely saved by its awesome community. The "it's fixed now" narrative is a total lie. Avoid.

I bought this game because it was 8$. I knew the drama that has surrounded the game for years. I came into the game with an open mind and even purchased the 12.99$ subscription to get a 'private world'. I can NOT recommend this game to anyone.

I play with a 4080 super and 32 gb of DDR5. The stuttering 'jitteryness' of the graphics is unacceptable. The graphics themselves are dated, which is expected from Bethesda. The quests so far have been straight ass. Random raiders and settlers with no though made to their persons whatsoever. Sometimes houses and buildings do not load properly and youll see random items floating in a half empty house, with AI settlers staring mindlessly into a random corner. Some enemies take no damage because they are part of quests, guess the game isnt really open world then is it.The nickle and dime nature of the atom shop is incredibly off putting, like really, slight updates to existing assets from previous games and your charging for them? The gunplay is mid, even compared to Fo4. There seems to be, from my point of view, a clear push to make the game seem as addicting as possible, in a manner by which players will shovel out more money to 'get to the good parts'. I will probably play for at least 10 hours more before updating this review, with friends, but as of now this game seems incredibly scummy. There are dozens of overhaul mods for 3, NV, and 4 which do much better jobs at creating new or altered fallout games than this. AND THEY ARE FREE.

I played for several years since this game came out, and at first, it was great. I actually enjoyed playing this game. Still, I can't get into the game, and not because the game is bad; the story is actually good. However, many things make the game unplayable. For example, this game came out 5 years ago and still lacks cross-progression or cross-platform play, whereas many games in this genre offer one or the other, or both. It blows my mind how the devs do not implement that yet. Overall, the gameplay is what you expect from a Fallout game, but it feels constrained by the ancient engine it runs on. The constant bugs and performance issues, even after years of patches, are a nagging reminder that the technical foundation is simply not suited for a modern online, open-world experience.

It's a game of two halves: a genuinely engaging post-apocalyptic world and story that manages to pull you back in, contrasted with a frustrating, archaic infrastructure that is struggling to support a live-service model. The lack of basic modern features like cross-progression isn't just an oversight; it's a symptom of a larger technical hurdle that the developers have admitted is difficult to clear, which leaves dedicated long-time players feeling ignored and essentially forces you to choose a single platform, further segmenting an already niche player base.

You stick with it for the unique blend of exploration and lore, but the persistent jankiness, server instability, and archaic quality-of-life failings are the trade-off, and for many, that trade-off is finally becoming too much to bear. I will continue to play this game and actually do recommend it, but it's just many things, as I mentioned make the game sometimes unbearable to play. I hope they continue to add more and fix it.

Definitely one of the worst launches in Bugthesda's storied history but also for the Fallout Franchise until Starmid came along and swept that all away. After many little updates and a decent amount of major ones with another coming soon alongside Season 2 of the show in December FO76 has come a long way to being a rather decent title in the franchise. It sadly retains the MMO/Live service parts in the game although they are light I'd rather they just not really exist but what can you do. 

However the main story and updates that brought new stories to Appalachia are rather good and I actually do reccomend playing this either solo or in a small group and just take in what West Virginia has to offer in a very beautiful and varied environments. 

The gunplay is retained from FO4 and while it is good for FO4 it does feel they could of perfected it further, here it still can feel floaty and not beefy in both feel and audio. I will say the variety of weapons added are good although it does puzzle me why we haven't had more classic Fallout weapons such as the Chinese Assualt Rifle, .32 special revolver, 9MM pistol to name a few which sucks. 

Overall I would recommend highly on sale of 70% or more off as I reckon with the free major updates and new and continued events alongside one of the genuinely best, caring, kind, and friendliest communities I have ever experienced in video games you can't really go wrong with Fallout 76 these days.

Also won't someone on YT make a solid video doing a update on how far this game has come from it's launch I think streamers and the public are getting false ideas from outdated videos such as the InternetHistorian (the Plagiarizer he is) video that this game is still absolute dogwater of which it is not. It's more like freshly bottled radioactive water from a broken water purifier.

[i]Panem et circenses,[/i] or bread and circuses, originates from Rome in [i]Satire X[/i] by Roman satirical poet Juvenal. In context, Bread and Circuses identifies the only remaining interest of a Roman populace that no longer cares for its historical birthright of political involvement. Here Juvenal displays his contempt for the declining heroism of contemporary Romans, using a range of different themes, including lust for power and desire for old age to illustrate his argument. Roman politicians passed laws in 140 CE to keep the votes of poorer citizens by introducing a grain dole; giving out cheap food and entertainment, "bread and circuses," became the most effective way to rise to power. The phrase was and is used to imply an erosion or ignorance of a population's civic duty as a priority. Fitting, then, that the greatest modern proponent of a game glorifying that very act of ignorance has the same ignorance and eroded sense of public duty in all things.

In the early 3rd century CE, the Christian writer Tertullian condemned the attendance of Christians to attend gladiatorial games. The combats, he said, were murder, their witnessing spiritually and morally harmful, and the gladiator an instrument of pagan human sacrifice. 
[quote=Dr. Carolyn Osiek]The reason, we would suppose, would be primarily the bloodthirsty violence, but his is different: the extent of religious ritual and meaning in them, which constitutes idolatry. Although Tertullian states that these events are forbidden to believers, the fact that he writes a whole treatise to convince Christians that they should not attend [i](De Spectaculis)[/i] shows that apparently not everyone stayed away from them.[/quote]

In 325, Constantine the Great forbade criminals being forced to fight to the death as gladiators, declaring their sentence to serve in mines or other service that they may serve a real purpose with their blood. As the years went on, more Roman emperors would gradually ban the games further and further, including in the wake of Saint Telemachus' martyrdom by spectators at a gladiator [i]munus.[/i] Less than a century later, interest in gladiator combats had waned throughout the Roman empire, deemed an utter waste of money and a vile practice with no meaning nor glory.

In the Byzantine empire, the post-transition Roman empire, theatrical shows and chariot races would attract the crowds instead, drawing a generous imperial subsidy, but the gladiators would never find purpose again.

10/10 simulation of the decline of Gladiator games, wouldn't recommend even if it was being sold still.

I bought this game in like 2018 and played for something like 5 hours. Nothing wrong with it, but one of a bunch of games in my Steam library at this point, by 2022 I really wasn't thinking about it much. 

Then out of nowhere it starts popping up in my library news feed. Fair enough, looked like a lot of drama that I wasn't going to bother digging into. 

Latest update just appears to be either trolling or staunchly phobic or in the process of a very public mental breakdown? If the dev wants to work that hard at being offensive for a 4-year-old game that hasn't seen any substantial updates or additions in all that time, it only seems fair that for my belated review I give it a downvote. If this dev had been this public about being this offensive in 2018 I would have given it a pass anyway. It's not like I'm so worried about the personal beliefs of every game developer I'm going to waste time vetting everyone involved beforehand, but if you're going to be that vocal and wrong-headed it's pretty hard to ignore...

The game dev is an alt-right nuttjob that posts trans-phobic quips in his update logs and has recently started posting unhinged rants alongside small updates, then labels them as "Major Updates" so his bullshit shows up in a huge, obnoxious box when checking the update feed.

Aside from that, the actual game itself is actually pretty good, but there is still some severe criticism. Previously, there were gladiator classes that were locked behind the latest end-game tier research, meaning that they were very easily missed, and often underused. The developer decided to make these classes available to use at the very beginning of the game, but locked them behind a paywall, essentially stripping content from the game and repackaging it as DLC.

TL:DR If the developer's bigotry isn't enough to put you off from buying this game, his behavior and conduct as a developer should be more than enough to give you second thought. As an other reviewer had put it: The update log isn't your personal blog post, its a fucking update log. You're not writing update logs to make people laugh, persuade them, or whatever the fuck he's doing. You write update logs to *Drumroll* log your updates. Stripping content from the game and reselling it is also just shameful, and it insults people like myself whom have supported this game for quite a while.

Honestly, I really enjoyed the game and if the circumstances weren't so bad, I'd have recommended the game whole heartedly.

But with the circumstances the way they are, I cannot recommend you spend money on this game.

To summarise things:
- The dev liked to put political comments in with the patch notes for the game and whether or not they were jokes or completely serious, he received a lot of backlash for the recent one about telling people to take their masks off, in the middle of a pandemic, i might add, to which the dev decided he wanted to die on that hill and double and triple downed 

- This led to a downward spiral where the dev would decide to abuse the people who left negative reviews or comments around his statements from the patch notes and when that doesn't give the results he wanted then he would report the review or ban the person from commenting on the forum. This led to valve removing his ability to completely control his community hub because he was actively harassing his community because they didn't share his point of view on everything, he had a bit more of a meltdown and decided to stop updating the game on steam.

- The dev ended up having a huge tirade on twitter that also included abusing anyone who disagreed with his opinion and blocking them when he couldn't come up with good enough comebacks, throwing in homophobic and transphobic comments to anyone who even seemed related to those communities. 

Do I recommend the game? Yes, it is a good game and although a bit difficult the first few times you play through, there is a satisfaction to completing the game with out losing any of your gladiators.

Do I recommend you buy the game? No, The dev is acting like a child and refuses to accept his attitude is the reason for this whole mess, he has also made an attempt at a cash grab by taking things that were already in the beta branch for the base game and repackaged them into paid DLC without changing anything about them. I don't say this lightly but if you can pirate the game, then pirate it, because I don't believe this person deserves your money.

Edit: The dev has now decided that the best course of action instead of apologising to his community, to double down again in the most recent patch notes (1st Sept 2022) and slightly change the name of the game as well as poke fun at the trans community. Here is the notes in case they get removed in the future:

Posted Thur. 1 September 2022.
DOMINUS v1.3.25 (deadname: domina)
Please Respect Our Pronouns During This Difficult Transition

We're Out of Ideas, Mentally Unstable, Totally Degenerate, & Desperate for Clout - Lets Pretend We're A Completely Different Game to Regain Relevance!

deadname: domina. Please don't mention it any more. We only mention it here to say: don't mention it any more. It's totally normal to change the sex of a video game and NOT CONFUSING TO ANYBODY. Please do not be a bigot. If you are confused, please simply stop being confused and remember that DOMINA doesn't exist and never did, but DOMINUS does exist, and always has, you just didn't know you were playing a man, who was dressed as a woman, but now that we reveal it to you, you have NO RIGHT to feel deceived, the same way the poor drunk dudes who transvestites like Keffals had sexual intercourse with, without disclosing that they were a man, have no right to feel wronged and you're a bigot for being confused or even mentioning something like that happening, let alone having an opinion about it.
It's a no from me, boss.

Honestly, the game kind of sucks. The combat is really low-effort and simple when you take over your units, and when you don't control them the AI is pretty bad and not really fun to watch. The management aspect feels more timer-y than fun and management-y, and mostly ends up boiling down to grinding basic stats so you can keep destroying all the lousy AI's competition with direct control, until random RNG catches up to you. Needed much stronger management mechanics and a more hands-off approach to combat. Add to that the really bad RNG reliance and the pretty shitty DLC practices, and it's a solid not recommended from me. Watching the dev implode in the patch notes is more entertaining than the game, so just browse that instead.

CS2 still delivers that tight, chess-with-guns feeling I keep coming back for. Shots land the way your crosshair says they should, movement has a clean rhythm, and smokes and flashes reward actual planning instead of guesswork. The new tech makes clutches feel steady under pressure, and a good execute is as satisfying as ever.

There are off nights. Matchmaking ranges from solid to puzzling, and cheater stories never fully disappear. Even so, a small bit of practice and a regular duo turn the curve into momentum. If you want structured rounds, clear feedback, and real improvement you can feel from week to week, this is the one to play.

Shit game! In this modern era of games, specially FPSs, not having ADS and "bullets flying away in every direction" makes the game not playable for me. It was good back in the 1.6 and source days but back then those were all we had in case of PVP FPSs! I know some people may get pissed off about my comment on guns recoils so let me explain : In other FPS games (R6, COD, etc) when you ADS (which you cant even do that in CS) and shoot, the gun moves and your crosshair in the gun's sight goes up and you can control it by pulling your mouse down and then, YOUR BULLETS HIT WHERE YOU'RE AIMING AT! but in CS, your bullets start flying in every direction after the 1st bullet and only your hip-fire cross hair (sooooo realistic that they never ADS with AK an M4 cause you know, THEY DON'T ADS IN REAL LIFE SO THAT'S SOOOO REALISTIC) goes nuts in every direction which makes it impossible to control which ends up with situations like you firing a gun slowly and 1 bullet every 1 sec to make sure that it hits where you aim (which it absolutely doesn't!). CS fans defend this by saying it's for the realistic aspect of the game, which to that I say: WHY CAN'T I FACKIN ADS IF ITS REALISTIC? THERE'S LITERALLY AN IRON SIGHT IN TOP OF MY GUN AND I CAN'T USE IT TO ADS? DON'T YOU ADS WHEN YOU SHOOT A REAL GUN? So overall, IMO this game is only alive because of the people who trade CS skins, the 30 yos who play for nostalgia and ape-heads who don't want to learn to play an actual good FPS and want only gun-fight (which this game sucks at THAT, too!)
