This game is absolute chaos in the most beautiful way possible. CS2 right now feels like standing in a hurricane made of trade ups and broken dreams. The new gold trade up system has completely flipped the market on its head. Billions gone, collectors crying, traders panicking, everyone mashing F5 on Buff trying to figure out what anything’s worth anymore. It’s madness. And yet, it’s kind of glorious. Every time I throw five red skins into the void, my heart rate doubles, and the chance of gold feels like pure electricity. The game itself looks gorgeous, plays like I’m gliding through butter, and still crashes just often enough to remind me Valve hates stability. Movement’s weird, smokes still behave like living organisms, but then you hit that one perfect headshot and everything clicks. The dopamine hits, the addiction resets, and suddenly it’s the best game ever again. CS2 right now is gambling, art, and misery stitched together by nostalgia. It’s broken, beautiful, and completely unstoppable. 10/10, pure ecstasy and suffering in perfect balance.

I would recommend the game if not for the community.

CS2 feels like a clean rebuild of the thing I kept playing for years. The gunplay is crisp, recoil patterns are readable, and the sub-tick update makes clutches feel fair instead of slippery. When utility is planned and trades are tight, rounds have that satisfying click where everything makes sense.

It is not perfect. Matchmaking quality swings, and trust in anti-cheat depends on the week. But with a regular stack or a bit of practice, the skill expression and round-by-round mind games more than pay off. If you want structured competition with real stakes in every peek and rotate, this is still the place to be.

I learned to love Dota 2 by playing support at 2 AM, buying wards I swore I couldn’t afford, and watching a hopeless lane become winnable because the map finally made sense. This game is a long conversation with your past self. Yesterday you overextended for one more range creep. Today you drag the wave, plant a sentry on instinct, and live to tell the story.

The magic is how cause and effect stay visible. Win a fight near an objective and the whole river tilts in your favor. Lose a fight with buybacks down and you can feel the punishment in your bones. Patches change the surface, but the logic underneath remains readable. If you pay attention, Dota forgives slower than most games, and teaches faster than you expect.

People joke that nothing feels better than a rampage, but my favorite moments are quieter. A smoke that threads the needle between two wards. A carry who trusts a risky call because you pinged it with confidence. A glimpse of a courier path that gives away an ancient stack. These are tiny, human victories that never show up on the scoreboard and somehow matter most.

If you are new, you do not need encyclopedic knowledge. Learn why vision wins fights. Learn that it is okay to trade farm for tempo. Mute early when needed and keep the chat wheel for jokes, not judgment. Pick two or three heroes that make you curious and keep them until your hands know the buttons before your brain does. There is a day when you stop panicking at the minimap and start reading it. That day changes everything.

To the folks at Valve, thank you for making a competitive game that still feels handcrafted. The silhouettes remain readable, the replays are a gift, and the client gets out of the way when it matters. If I could ask for anything, it would be richer first hour guidance and more guardrails around early social friction. The moment someone feels their first real swing of agency, they stay.

I recommend Dota 2 because it stays interesting in the small details long after the big ones are familiar. It is stubborn, brilliant, occasionally infuriating, and somehow the perfect place to spend a late night with four names you may never meet and a plan that might actually work. See you on the high ground.

Lets talk about apex legends....  This game launched back in February of 2019, and man oh man it was a hit. That being said Respawn did everything in their power to destroy it so lets talk about it.

1. The movement.....
I'm not normally a huge fan of the extreme fast paced movement but Titanfall had it perfect and when Apex Legends came out they nailed perfectly. It felt fun and exciting but now, not so much chief.
You see I'm not sure why they did it but they went and made Apex Legends, Chunky Legends. I'm not sure if this was a community complaint or or a ranked complaint or even Respawn just sippin the juice too hard but this feels horrible now. It just kills the parkour and sprint feature, I shouldn't have to slide down a hill for a boost in speed. 

2. The guns.....
Respawn did this really cool thing where they brought all the guns from Titanfall and just molested them.
You see they went and looked into the fan favorite weapons and nerfed the life out of them to switch up the meta, but the weapons were fine! Honestly this wouldn't be a bad thing if they buffed them after a while but that's just it, they never get buffed back! Every gun feels like a I'm hitting them with with pillows. You're forced to just puke all your ammo out on one guy because every time you do damage he just runs away and shields back up and rinse and repeat until one of you either runs out of shields or ammo. You make a competitive game and then try to hard to make it  "player friendly" and just turned it into a bullet hose arena

3.The characters.
(this one is my personal opinion so feel free to blow past this one) There are so many characters and they cost an arm and a leg to unlock. Half of them are absolutely useless and feel like gimics. The skins are kinda cringe too at times, not all of them but most of them.

4.The Store...
I know the game is free and the store is where they make money but the prices on the items, oh my god.
like 20+ dollars for a majority of the items in the store. It just feels scummy and it's giving wallet reaching big time. Respawn is just becoming activision 2.0.

I think that wraps it up for me. This game used to be such a gem but like all things on earth, aging kills (unless your a lobster) It does feel sad though because this game really speed ran the whole "killing my own community" strat within a year I would say. They already announced that there wasn't gonna be a Titanfall 3 so this was the only brainchild in the works to my knowledge which just feels like the thing they care about is collecting card info now and not the Titanfall arena experience this game is built around. Stay away from this game and let it go peacefully into the night. Lest Respawn does anymore harm before it does.

In the first summer of its launch, the game originally drew me in with its story, characters, and universe. It had a gritty and interesting style of storytelling that eventually got me into Titanfall 2 -- now one of my sci-fi story loves. Unfortunately, my love affair with Apex Legends' storytelling and universe has long since been on the decline ever since they've been whittling down their writing team; most of the narrative/writing direction have now left and gone on to other, better prospects. The love that used to go into the community is now nonexistent compared to the days they had a social media/community manager that EA then fired. A lot of characters now fall into the Overwatch trap of getting released constantly and then receiving zero lore/attention.

In terms of technical stuff, the game was buggy in its initial years of launch, and now is *mostly* stable for most people. Unfortunately, it is not optimised for everyone, and I am in that camp. Most days I'm unable to launch this game without opening it 4-5 times. Getting constant lag warnings (literally all the symbols) in most games and on most days, with fibre internet and an all right PC. 

The biggest joke is that I'm still playing this game, but I like shooting things + I hate change and seeking out new media. For anyone looking into something new to get into for the story and lore and community, honestly, just find a different game. It's not getting better from here on out.

This game is genuinely the worst game of my life. You can go one single game without playing against people who are the highest rank in the game or ALGS pros. There is not a single reason why someone who has never been above platinum 2 can get into a game with someone who has played in official tournaments. Eventually me and my friend were tired of it and decided to play on alt accounts to hopefully not play against highest rank people, but 3 games in and we were no match for the top 500. I believe this is a result of the poor decisions made by Respawn. They have done nothing but absolutely ruin their game. Marksmen rifles have the highest fastest TTK in the game, the playable character made around movement has the least movement in the game, duos has half the players in it and half the map already covered by zone, and the list goes on. It even got to the point that some pros have quit. The player count is at an all time low for a reason. Today it took me over 8 minutes for me to get into a game, just for it to end in 2 minutes because one of the top 500 players in the world absolutely desecrated me. At this point I cant even accidentally have fun in this game. If your ever even thinking about trying this game, I implore you not to.

The ranked system also sucks. Placement is waaaay above getting kills, so final zone will tend to have like 10 teams in it all sitting in corners of the zone trying to widdle the other teams down. All in all, go play Titanfall 2, this was NOT the Titanfall 3 I wanted :(

💥🏃‍♂️ BROOO APEX LEGENDS ITU ROYALE PALING CEPAT, PALING CHAOTIC, DAN PALING STYLISH! 💥

Bayangin lo dilempar ke arena futuristik, 60 orang saling bunuh demi jadi yang terakhir berdiri. Tapi bedanya, ini bukan battle royale biasa, ini parkour, skill, dan teamwork dalam satu paket gila!

⚡ Gameplay? FUSION ANTARA SPEED & STRATEGY!
Lo bisa sliding ngebut di lereng, zipline dari atap ke atap, trus tiba-tiba flank musuh dari arah nggak terduga. Setiap karakter punya skill unik dari healer, trap master, sampe teleport ninja. Lo nggak cuma nembak, tapi juga ngerencanain tiap langkah kayak taktik perang modern.

🔫 Gunplay-nya? CLEAN BANGET.
Recoil-nya terasa realistis, tiap senjata punya feel dan suara khas. Dari Wingman yang satisfying banget pas kena headshot, sampe R-99 yang literally nyemprot peluru kayak air mancur.

🤝 SQUAD PLAY = INTI SEGALANYA.
Main sendiri sih bisa, tapi Apex itu hidup dari kerjasama tim. Lo bakal saling cover, ping lokasi musuh, revive temen di tengah hujan peluru, dan panik bareng pas ring udah nutup. Komunikasi di sini tuh hal paling penting dan paling chaos juga. 😂

🎨 VISUAL & MAP? BERASA FUTURISTIK TAPI HIDUP.
Dari gurun Kings Canyon sampe kota neon di Olympus, semua map-nya detail banget. Warna vibrant, efek ability keren, dan design karakternya bergaya sci-fi yang beda banget dari battle royale lain.

🎵 AUDIO = CLUTCH MOMENT MAKER.
Suara langkah musuh, zipline, atau ultimate Horizon yang mulai aktif, semuanya bisa jadi bedain hidup dan mati. Headset wajib, bro.

🌟 Rating: 9/10
Apex Legends = battle royale buat lo yang suka adrenalin tinggi, teamwork solid, dan gameplay secepat kilat. Gue balik dulu, masih ada squad yang nge-hold high ground. Wish me luck, bro. Octane gue udah siap ngebut! 🏃‍♂️💨💥

As before this game I played Titanfall 2 and Call of Duty, I will try to make this comparison based on those.

This is a unique game, meaning if you are the average cod playing Joe, u won't just be a god here with good aims. The healing system is slower than in cod, so you cant just fully reheal mid fight, here u need to have an edge. Maps are more punishing meaning, there is always cover, but there are massive walls on every map so u need to be careful where u rotate otherwise u are going to be stuck outside. Weapons are solid, not huge recoil, its learnable. Movement is interesting, because at first it feels extremely rigid, then when u learn what to do and how, it can be really fast and fluid. 

What I want to say: this is a skill needed game, I think more than cod. Plus in its current state it is kinda abandoned by devs, but it runs, finds matches fast and that is about enough.

Apex Legends stands out as one of the best battle royale games ever made, combining fast-paced gunplay, smooth movement, and unique Legends that keep every match fresh and exciting. The teamwork-focused gameplay and constant updates make it incredibly replayable, and Respawn’s attention to detail shines through in every aspect of the game.

However, the experience is sometimes held back by persistent server issues, including lag and connection drops, especially frustrating since there are still no dedicated servers in Africa. Despite these setbacks, Apex Legends remains a thrilling, well-designed shooter that rewards skill, strategy, and communication.

Verdict: A top-tier battle royale with unmatched gameplay — if only the servers could keep up. ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆

my game

I went into Rust thinking I’d build a small base, hunt some animals, and maybe make a few friends. Instead, I learned what true despair feels like.

As a solo, every day is a new horror movie. You spend three hours farming wood, stone, and scrap, finally craft a gun, and then—boom—three guys in matching hoodies and AKs roll up in a minicopter, vaporize you in 0.2 seconds, and then type “ez” in chat.

You finally build a tiny 2x2 base you’re proud of? Congrats! It’ll be offline raided by a 6-man clan before you even wake up. You log back in to a pile of ash and regret.

Rust isn’t a survival game. It’s a suffering simulator disguised as one. The building, the looting, the gunplay—they’re all great. But the balance? Nonexistent. Unless you have a full squad, a sleep schedule that matches the server’s wipe cycle, and nerves of steel, you’re just free loot for bigger groups.

There’s nothing quite like hearing the whir of a minicopter above your head, knowing it’s not Santa—it’s a death squad.

Still, I keep coming back. Why? I have no idea. Maybe I’m just addicted to pain.

This game scratches 5 game itches for me. I don't think I've ever had something like this. I love it so much even though it's in early access and has a lot of bugs and glitches. I usually end up hating early access games especially pricey early access games because they don't deliver. They end up getting really popular then what I assume is happening, is they're taking all of the money (because either they want to cash in right away or they're funding another game and not making anymore content even though they promised they would.)

For example, they're planning to make Palfarm. While I'm also excited that they're making Palfarm I hope they continue making content for Palworld and tweaking stuff like:

- The capture rate for example I feel like is ass in the lower levels even if you tweak the settings.

- Flying doesn't feel good. It uses stamina but using a water pal for swimming doesn't use stamina. It doesn't make any sense. Especially since the world is massive. Taking breaks and landing to wait for the flying stamina is crazy.

- The ball mechanic is kinda weird. There is a module that curves when you throw it, it supposedly catches the pals off guard and increases capture power. It does neither and/or there is no difference than just throwing it normally unless you are really good at aiming because the head shot helps capture. I however, suck at aiming especially in fights where I'm kinda fumbling the controls. That is just my skill issue but still.

- I keep getting clipped into the mountains when I'm climbing or fighting pals, especially if they have knock back. I use the rocks to cancel their line of sight but sometimes I'm too late to dodge and it happens.

- The soldiers from the sanctuary chasing you for a long time. Sometimes they disengage but other times they follow you forever and most times, I need to quit the game for them to disengage.

There's so much things to do and I love that it has multiplayer. It runs ok in my potato computer. It's what I wish the pokemon games were like but it's sadly not and not to mention nintendo is super greedy.

⭐ Summary:
Pretty solid game overall. It runs fine even on older hardware, but the A.I. pathing and some optimization issues really need fixing.
Still, for an indie dev team, it’s totally worth the price fun, satisfying, and full of potential.

✅ Pros:

-The game’s pretty solid so far.
-Pal designs are kinda mid but still fine a few are actually really cool and memorable.
-The gameplay loop is great: build your base, catch some Pals, and make them work for you super satisfying to watch.
-You can ride them too, which is just pure fun.
-QoL features are surprisingly decent.

❌ Cons:

-The biggest issue right now is the A.I. pathing it’s straight-up terrible, especially around the Oil Rig area.
-Your Pals often get stuck doing nothing, making fights frustrating if you rely on them.

Really hope the devs fix this soon, because the rest of the game is great.

💻 Performance / Optimization:

Optimization is both good and bad. The latest updates made it run fine even on older systems that’s a big plus.

However, on older GPUs like the GTX 1050 2GB, the FPS drops massively when looking toward the middle of the map (the Anubis boss area).

Even with draw distance set to low, frames still tank hard.

It feels like the game forces too much stuff into view distance, which really hurts old hardware.

I wish they’d tweak that I don’t need to see Papalagos Mountain all the way from Faybreak Island anyway 😅

💬 Final Thoughts:
For an indie dev team, they’ve done an awesome job regular free updates, stable performance overall, and lots of potential ahead.
Totally worth the price even at full price, no discount needed. 👍

I didn’t expect to like Palworld as much as I do, but it really hits that perfect mix of all the games I grew up loving. It has the collecting and raising aspect that reminds me of those old monster companion games, the exploration and discovery of open world adventures, and the strategic battles that scratch the same itch as card and team building games.

What I love most is how everything connects. Building and upgrading my base feels meaningful, not just something you do between missions. My pals actually help out around the place, gathering materials, crafting, and defending it when raids happen. It’s oddly satisfying watching them all work together while I plan out what to build next.

Exploring the world is just as fun. There’s always something new to find, whether it’s a hidden cave, a new type of pal, or a tough fight that forces me to rethink my team setup. It feels like the game constantly rewards curiosity.

It also scratches that collector brain of mine without feeling like a grind. Finding a new pal, learning what they can do, and figuring out where they fit into my setup feels really rewarding. It reminds me of a mix between raising digital monsters, building decks, and running a base all at once.

Palworld just clicks for me in a way few games do. It takes all these mechanics I’ve liked in other games and somehow makes them all work together naturally. I keep telling myself I’ll just log in for a bit to check on my base, and then three hours disappear.
It's what Pokemon wishes it could be!

Alright so, this game is definitely better than Pokémon, at least because the last game release is, well, Z-A. Sadly my device can't run the game very well for long periods of time even with my graphic settings bordering potato quality and using extra software to improve performance, but it still was and is very enjoyable to play though the grind did feel kind of extreme at first, that at least until I used certain settings so, maybe it's not that accessible for people without top-quality devices but it certainly let's you define how frustrating gathering resources can be at the more late-ish states of the game.

Gameplay wise it's pretty much what you'd expect, craft'n'gun with a hell of a lot of crafting and raiding, mostly NPCs because I certainly haven't tried playing multiplayer (My PC thanks me for that) yet it can be pretty enjoyable on the lonesome. Not that much story aside of the collectable journals but then again, most people don't even play these capture-and-battle-monsters games for the story. Maybe the worst aspect of the gameplay is that most of the battle progression is just that your items/companions deal more damage and you resist more so there isn't much depth to it, nothing really outstanding for that part aside of the fact most items that actually have a unique aspect to how they work tend to be way more situational.

About the Pals, honestly, I can see the "plagiarism" people was crying about for certain designs but then again, I think the ones that should've tried speaking up for that should be Digimon because those are FAR more similar if you ask me. Still, aside of the "This one looks similar to..." comment, it feels a little exaggerated.

Buy it if you like open-world games and the concept of Pokémon, or to make a statement that Nintendo will never even bother thinking of bringing up. Your money at the end of the day.

If the Minecraft Pokemon mod, Unturned, Monster Hunter and FORTNITE had a baby. 

This game offers insane amounts of content, backed by infinite amounts of grinding, so despite the game technically not having an end goal, you really can't stop playing it because the game doesn't give you everything it has to offer right away. You only find out as you explore, making you even more excited to play. 
There's 1 open world which seems massive (I haven't explored it fully yet), stacked with "Pals" (cute Pokemon ahh creatures that you can butcher with a meat cleaver btw), countless resources, boss dungeons filled with loot, beautiful landscapes, secrets, collectibles and more. If you're lucky, you might even encounter a shiny Pal, just like in Pokemon games. Although they seem much more rare here.
I previously mentioned the game not having an end goal, but it applies in the traditional sense only (no ender dragon type final boss you're preparing for), instead you have personal missions to catch a certain amount of Pok- Pals, craft certain items, and early in the game you're introduced to some high level bosses you can't tackle just yet, which is a good psychological tactic to give the player some goal right away - to catch that high level, boss Pal. But then as you play, you find many more and you're stuck in an endless loop of finding things you want but can't have just yet, making you play more & more.

You are also introduced into a deep, complex, yet addictive base building system that contains separate missions, ways of enslaving your Pals to work on the base, gather supplies, and overall make your virtual home a very lively experience. Ranking up your base feels rewarding, because you know you worked for everything you get (Pals that work day and night don't get credit cause fu*k 'em).

❗The game still being in early access does come with certain flaws, such as bugs and some gameplay mechanics that can definitely be improved. I will name a few.
-if you summoned your Pal to fight someone, and there's an object in between (even a tree), sometimes the Pal will keep throwing its moves at the object, until either the enemy or your pal moves to a side where they can hit each other. Same applies if you summon a Pal on grounds above or below the enemy, they will just stay confused instead of finding a way to jump down or up to hit the enemy. Your only solution then is to run to a spot where they can fight, risk getting hit by the enemy, then re-summon your Pal.
-if you attack those positive vibes NPCs, you should just restart the game. At that point, you become *wanted* like in GTA, and level 40 (which is high) police guys with assault rifles CHASE YOU TO THE ENDS OF THE EARTH. LITERALLY. You can teleport to a different side of the map, they will spawn near you and gun you down. You can climb a f**ing mountain, they will spawn on top waiting to gun you down. You can only get lucky escaping them by doing God knows what, or just restarting your session. I'm all for a difficult experience escaping, but make it a little bit more realistic ffs.
-if you make your character to be obese, cosmetics will glitch out making you look like you don't have an arm and more. You can also roll into a piece of rock sometimes and glitch into the wall requiring you to roll back out for 2 minutes. 

❗Important: many people, including myself, complain that catching a Pal feels less personal when you play online, because if you employ that Pal to the base, players in your guild can literally just steal it and put it in their box, and you can't do anything about it. You obviously guard yourself from this by playing with people you trust, but the game should still write somewhere which player caught a specific Pal, because sometimes you forget which Pal in the base is yours, and which one "belongs" to your guild members. 

A solution for this would be making a 3rd section where guild members can "unassign" your Pals and put in, but not steal, and only the player that caught it can take it back. The username of the player that caught each Pal should also be written on the Pal description so there are no confusions. 
On top of this, introducing a proper trading system would be required for this to work. I am hopeful that the developers will eventually fix this.

This game has insane amounts of potential and I am definitely excited for future updates and expansions, hopefully they also introduce a completely new map instead of just expanding the main one. 

I strongly recommend this game if you want something that will not get boring at all, to enjoy with friends or by yourself.

Honestly, Palworld surprised me in the best way. Catching Pals, fighting bosses, exploring different biomes, and riding around on mounts. It’s just fun. The mix of survival, base building (with good decorative options to make it your own), and creature collecting works way better than I thought it would.

Every time I think I’ve seen it all, I find a new Pal or a cool area to explore. The world feels alive, and it’s super easy to lose hours just building, fighting, or cruising around on my favorite mount.

If you enjoy games like Pokémon or even Minecraft in the building and exploration aspect, but want something fresh (and kinda hilarious at times), give this a go. Totally worth it.

Make no mistake, the designs of Pals seem to borrow their DNA from [i]a certain other creature-catcher[/i] in places, with a small number of particularly egregious examples in the pre-update Paldeck (Verdash I cannot hate you no matter your crimes). Even with that in mind, this was almost immediately a pleasant surprise to play despite my expectations of it being a tonal whiplash simulator. Base-building and management is fun, combat is enjoyable, and there's plenty of world to explore too. Despite the somewhat slow overall pace and rough edges of early access, the world settings are entirely customizable which can ease woes in the meantime. I'd say it's worth a shot!

My first gaming console was a SNES at the age of 3 going on 4. Growing up in a very bad household where I was forced into a car for a couple years of my life and losing my summer breaks with other kids, I played Pokemon Yellow and Gold on the Gameboy pocket in silence while my step dad drove for 10-16 hours each day around southern Texas... So, believe me, I was a huge fan of Pokemon. Loved Rare with Donkey Kong, StarFox, and Banjo Kazooie. I loved Kirby a LOT and still do.

This is coming from a former dye hard Nintendo Soyjack. Even someone who felt the burn of Creativerse being dumped for Palworld...
This game is worth your time and money.
I love that it's more focused on breeding and actually catching them all. That you aren't limited in customization for Pal's or for bases, something I wish Pokemon Emerald kept in newer versions of the series.
And listen... If you still love Nintendo, you even love the new Pokemon ZA, if it means anything to you, I played Pokemon Snap when BlockBuster offered the kiosks to print off stickers of the high scores I made. I even played Pokemon Stadium with the GB controller pak attachment for Gold/Silver and yes I got the Snorlax beanbag chair from it and was blown away by something not many people knew about, at least during the time the internet was JUST starting to include gaming guides for popular releases in a text file.

I ran through the Safari zones to get the rare Chansey's to breed, I revived the fossils on Cinnabar Island, I caught the Ho-oh, Mewtwo, and one of the three legendary Janto defenders. So, I can tell you from someone who used to treasure those moments, Palworld has recaptured that feeling I used to get playing Yellow, Gold, and Emerald. It feels like a true spiritual successor, regardless of Nintendo stating otherwise with their disgusting recent actions. No, I'm not just talking about the stupid patent war or them suing Palworld. I think the most absurd thing Nintendo has done recently is, in fact, the new Pokemon ZA... It feels like such a slap in the face to Nintendo fans when Palworld CONTROLS better than.
I felt the same way I did when I got that Snorlex decoration or printing out Pokemon Snap stickers when Terraria did a collab with Palworld. I got excited like when I started a base in Emerald when the new Farming Sim was announced (and I will be buying it because I am also a somewhat fan of Animal Crossing).

If you are a Pokemon fan, I am telling you, from a fan of the series before the Switch 2 came out, before a key member of Nintendo died (Rest his soul, iykyk), you will love Palworld, even with the bugs... which as someone who played a lot of the three Pokemon titles mentioned had more than it's far share of bugs, as well, with no way to patch it. It's got everything I wish Scarlet had when I saw playthroughs (because I was broke at the time when it released). It's a good paced game that heavily rewards if you breed and hatch eggs to gain better traits, merge bad traits with a favorite Pal to raise their rank, and/or fill the compendium, or if you complete higher level dungeons.

My score is Lamball out of Pikachu following you in Pokemon Yellow (so like a 11 out of 10). I highly recommend this soon to be classic.

It truly is a great game. There's a lot of content that you can progress through, and there's a lot of ways to optimize things, which is the really fun part for me. Trying to figure out how to build in a way that you get around the basic structure of the game keeps me interested. Is there a better option, is there another way, what else could I do, what am I missing? All of this stuff keeps your attention, and the greatest part is that when you find something, the Devs don't try to restrict you and force you into playing only the way that they want, the way that all of the other games do that kill them. They're games, they're supposed to be fun. I currently have a 6 wall high base, 2 levels that are 3 high each, there's 9 beds stacked on top of each other and 6 of those stacks, breaking the mechanics of the game for increased optimization, and I have 4 ranches stacked on top of each other with a bunch of Pals crowded around the first level pumping out resources. If I get annoyed with something, like a giant Pal who takes up too much space in the base just because they have the best starting skill level, there are ways to investigate and solve that issue by getting the smallest Pal in the entire game, with the lowest starting skill possible, and growing them to be even better than the basic level that the larger Pal started at. Even when everything gets stale, which all games eventually do, after a break, I am actually interested to getting back to the game, but I can't say that about the vast majority of games out there.

game_name: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II
review_text:
With 2019's [b]Modern Warfare[/b] I got drawn back into the [b]Call of Duty[/b] series, but all the good-will I felt about the series since then has slowly been eroded over the last few years.
Call of Duty and especially [b]Warzone[/b] have never been more player unfriendly, if not downright hostile.
Insane prices for store items of ever decreasing quality.
Low effort Battle passes you can only finish if you take up playing Call of Duty as your second job.
Constant upselling at every opportunity, even in your 70 Euros premium title.

This series is not worth the financial and time investment anymore.
At least not for me.

game_name: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II
review_text:
Call of Duty: Modern Warfare III: My 5000-Hour Diary of Being a Cheater Magnet in SBMM Hell 🌟
(Rating: 10/10 for "one more game" addiction, 0/10 for Ricochet anti-cheat, ∞/10 for "EZ noob uninstall" therapy)
Day 1: Hype Train Derails (2023 Launch)
Drop $70 on "full game." Campaign? 5 hours of Warzone reskins—feels like DLC for MW2. Multiplayer? Queue up, get matched with gods. Teammate 1: Octane wannabe slides off cliff. Teammate 2: Crypto drones himself. Me? P2020 spray-n-pray into a wall. Then cheater walls us with aimbot. "Welcome to MW3, paypig!"
Day 500: SBMM Says "Git Gud" (2024)
Hit Gold! Buy $20 bundle for that "meta" skin. Ranked? SBMM yeets me into Pred lobbies. Ping spikes to 200ms on Tokyo servers. Bullets? Ghost through enemies. Enemy: Cronus Zen kid with zero recoil beams me through smoke. Report? "Action taken" on my shadowban. Back to 150ms cheater lobbies.
Day 2000: Review Bomb Apocalypse (2025)
Grind battle pass for epic flatline blueprint. Activision: "Two passes/season, $20 each!" Steam goes Mostly Negative—"$70 DLC scam!" I uninstall... reinstall for Warzone integration. Cheaters? Banned 65k, but new ones spawn like zombies. Ricochet: "99% cheater-free!" Me: "In what universe?"
Day 3500: Cheater Chronicles Reloaded
Pred? Nah, Iridescent full of spinbots. Console "safe"? Cronus/XIM mag-dumps. PC? Wallhacks every 2/3 games. Watch death cam: Enemy snaps 180° through walls. Anti-cheat waves? Cheaters laugh, buy new accounts. I report 50, get "false positive" shadowban. Playing with bots now—literal ones.
Day 5000: Operator Overload
Main Ghost—OP! Nerf. Switch Soap—slide cancel queen! Nerf. Every gun: Buff week 1, trash week 2. Perks? Spam the meta 3. Spawns? Behind you, always. "Open Beta no SBMM" lied—full release is sweat factory. Every legend balanced like my K/D: 0.8 forever.
Sound & Graphics: Boom... Then Crash (Until Packet Loss)
Gunshots? Crisp pew-pew. Explosions? Hollywood BOOM. Then smoke—white void hell. Footsteps? Hear from orbit, yours? Muted. Controller vibrates mid-clutch... disconnects. "FUUUUUUUUCK MY LOADOUT!" Neighbors: "SWAT or COD?"
Community: Toxic Family Reunion

Russian: "CYKA SLIDE BLYAT" (dies first).
Solo savior: "Ping rez" (ghosts).
Me: "Group?" → Mute + "FEEDER NOOB."
Streamers: Hacked, DDOS'd. Pros: "Cheaters ruined ranked."

Optimization: Activision's Prank DLC
FPS: 300 firing range → 40 in TDM. Ping: 20 solo → 180 crossplay. Crashes: Mid-1v3 ace. Hitreg: Bullets teleport. "Server issues!" Every patch: 100GB download for "bug fixes" that add more bugs.
Conclusion: Why I Haven't Quit (Send Help)
MW3 isn't a game—it's a masochist simulator. Every loss: "Skill issue/SBMM/cheater?" Every win: God mode (rare). Spent $500 on bundles invisible in shadowban. Cheaters banned? Respawn tomorrow. But that one 20-kill game... pure crack.
Recommend if:

You love screaming at Cronus kids.
Training patience for 200ms peeks.
Broke but flex $1000 tracer packs.

Silver 4 Pro Tip:
"Teammate calls bot? 'At least I don't Cronus—your aim's Ricochet-free!' Roasted."
10/10 uninstalled... 5 mins later: "Queuing TDM."

game_name: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II
review_text:
Honestly disappointed with Activision at this point. Every time I just want to relax and play Warzone, I’m hit with the same “TRAVIS - RILEA” connection failed error. It’s frustrating that players have to constantly deal with login timeouts and server issues while there’s barely any proper communication or fix from the devs.

The game itself is great when it works — but the backend reliability and support are just unacceptable now. For a title backed by such a big studio, players deserve stable servers and timely updates. Please, Activision, focus on fixing your infrastructure before adding more content.

game_name: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II
review_text: Fun game with great core gameplay, but the matchmaking is completely broken. As a Diamond player on Rebirth, I'm constantly paired with much lower-ranked teammates who are still learning. This creates a frustrating experience for everyone; my games become a slow, unwinable slog trying to carry, while the newbies on my team just get stomped by the enemy's full squad of experienced players. It's a hellish cycle that punishes both ends of the skill spectrum.

game_name: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II
review_text:
as a long time player of CoD since Xbox, to PC, the franchise is broken. 

the last CoD i played was BO2, and loved every bit of it till the hacks, and cheats got to a point where i couldnt stand it anymore. 

i returned to to CoD with MW3, and heavily enjoyed it, and thought they improved their anti cheat.

then came BO6, which i preordered with high hopes, only to be let down. 

people dont even attempt to try to hide they are cheating. 

as a OG from xbox, xbox 360, to PC, the developers let us down. 

its sad to see CoD, and CS:GO be rewarded to the same group of people. 

DO NOT BUY. 

if you accept buying 3rd party programs or devices to have fun playing a FPS, then you were robbed of what it ment to have fun playing FPS for fun while being competitive

game_name: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II
review_text:
The CoD franchise has been THE go to shooter for most of my life. CoD is three or four kids dressed up in a trench coat pretending to be one person. Every year they release a brand new game. but then on top of that over they've also really gone super hard on stuffing skins and battle passes down our throats. I think it'd be forgivable if they were at least dropping without game breaking bugs. 
where are the millions of dollars going?! like at least use some of it to fix the flippin game right? I'm glad Battlefield is making a come back. Which means there's something fun to play that doesn't make me want to  off myself at the end of the night.

game_name: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II
review_text:
I across ps4 and pc I probably have 200 hours in this game. I am only leaving this review in the hopes that the big wigs running cod see this. The game used to be fun, I used to buy every title. I will never ever ever give any cod title my money ever again. I played COUNTLESS hours of warzone, mw,  mwII, mwIII, and the newer black ops. Nothing new is ever added into the game. It always feels like they use nostalgia in order to sell new titles NOT new features or better gameplay. I tried to come back to warzone and BO6 one last time before I leave the franchise forever but I simply cannot bring myself to play these games anymore. The original MW2 made me fall in love with video games, the state of cod right now makes me ashamed to know ive ever spent anytime playing these titles. Save your money, save your time. At this point ever since redsec dropped for battlefield I uninstalled warzone quick as heck. Every conversion kit and "meta" weapon build is cringe i hate everything about this game. It will never be warzone during early covid and ill remember that time fondly. 

TLDR: Do yourself a favor. Delete the game. Play battlefield 6. Stop giving this greedy scummy company your money. 

- Signed a lifetime cod gamer, no more.

LIke everyone else, I grew up playing Grand Theft Auto.

I do love them but I lost access to my old email that was unfortunately used for my Rockstar Games account and now I cannot boot this or any other Rockstar game using their 3rd party launcher (Red Dead, GTA IV, likely GTA VI).

Rockstar support seems to be a team of bots, sending me the exact same copy-pasted message with a different agent in the signature. Despite attaching proof, they just automatically close my ticket and I cannot reply, saying "We investigated" and now I can't access games I've spent hundreds of dollars on, and saves I've spend hundreds of hours on. They can't just unlink my Steam account from my Rockstar Games account, instead I can never play something made by them again as long as it uses their 3rd party launcher.

If the actions of this company past and present have proven one thing its that they just want you to buy their game as many times as possible.

The ultimate chill game.
Stardew Valley is honestly the best game for anyone who just wants to relax and discover new things at their own pace. Every playthrough feels different. I’m still learning new stuff every time I play, even after hours in the game. It’s cozy, peaceful, and somehow never gets old.

For something made by one person, it’s insanely impressive. ConcernedApe built a whole world that just pulls you in, from the farming and fishing to the characters and the music.

If you want a game that helps you unwind but still keeps you curious, this is it.
star poo saggy

This game is absolutely amazing, specially having in mind that it was originally made by Concerned Ape instead of a huge company. 

The story itself isn't quite amusing, but the whole game has an energy that simply just drags you in. The whole concept of inheriting a farm in the middle of nowhere and deciding to go there moved by the feeling of emptyness in your life is already calling. Also, I love the friendship mechanics and the fact that you can marry the bachellors; although some 14 heart events are boring. Besides, some festivities or special events (like Christmas and The Egg Hunt) are really exciting because they are more interactive. I would like The Egg Hunt more if the locations of the eggs changed every year though.

However, I must say that the game gets kind of repetitive if you're playing alone. I highly recomend you to play online, it's more thrilling and you can't predict what will happen through the day. Also, the skull caverns are kind of boring (in my opinion), and for others is the thing they hate the most about the game.

10/10
One of the greatest Rogue-likes.
Hades?  .
This game is absurdly overrated.

The first Hades was, no doubt in my mind, leagues ahead of Hades 2. Don’t get me wrong. Hades 2 is still good, but those 94 critic scores on Metacritic and OpenCritic feel a little high. I’d call it a solid 84 to 87.

The original Hades? That’s Mount Rushmore of PC gaming territory. Mid to high 90s, no question.

I like games that feel good for the soul and Hades did that in every way. The lore, story, and gameplay hooked me for hundreds of hours. A huge difference is The Infernal Arms were more fun and iconic than Melinoë’s options, with a heaviness to the hits. Playing as Zagreus put me in a full flow state.

I wanted to read every single line in Hades 1. Not so much in 2. I loved Persephone’s story. Finally finding her and getting to visit her those ten times before bringing her back was the perfect payoff.

The writing had a pulse and i could see myself in multiple characters. Even you Hades. You understand him by the end. And dare i say feel bad beating him. 

And the soundtrack. I usually just enjoy music in games enough, but this one stuck. I added extra playtime just to listen to “Good Riddance” and “On the Coast.” So if its on the metacritic scale i give it a 96. The third highest rated PC game of all time. I liked it so much I am going to now buy Super Giant's other games. I have the most hours played on Hades of all my PC games. It even has a doggy you can pet which makes it that much better!

It’s a really good game with a nice story, and the art is absolutely gorgeous. I don’t even want to start on the voice acting—it’s just fabulous. And the music? God, it’s so good.
The only part I really dislike is having to pursue the Olympians to unlock their hearts. God, it’s so painful. I was completely exhausted after doing 50–60 runs just waiting for that one blasted dialogue to finally appear. That part feels super frustrating.
And yeah, the game is tough. Once you hit 25+ Heat, things get insane—especially with Extreme Measures stacked on top. Hades himself just goes completely wild at that point.
At the end of the day though, it’s a fun game wrapped in a whole lot of pain.

One of the best rougelites I have ever played. The gameplay is fast and tight, the variety of weapons and enemies always keep you on your toes. The game is absolutely gorgeous, the art style is stellar, the overworld environments are gorgeous and the character arts show so much personality. Every single part of the game is voice acted by incredibly skilled voice actors, you can feel the emotion dripping from the performances.

one of the best roguelites/roguelikes/godlikes ive ever played, i love games that dont skimp out on important things like voice lines, and attention to detail even for the little things.

Hades is hands down the best roguelite I’ve ever played. Every single run feels rewarding — whether you win or lose, you’re always making progress. The combat is smooth and satisfying, the soundtrack absolutely bangs, and the art direction is top-tier.

What really sets it apart, though, is the storytelling — it’s genuinely interesting, something I didn’t expect from a roguelite. Characters evolve naturally over dozens of runs, and it never feels repetitive.

It took me around 75 hours to 100% the game, and even then, I wasn’t bored for a moment. The gameplay loop is addictive, the writing is clever, and the challenge scales perfectly as you grow stronger.

If it’s on sale, it’s a must-buy — but even at full price, you can’t go wrong.
10/10.

Pros:

-Stunning 2D art design with vibrant colors and creative visuals
-Immersive world and engaging story about escaping Hades
-Well-done narration and character interactions with gods like Poseidon and Zeus
-Rich story content and interesting characters
-No online competition; focus on interacting with in-game characters
-Fun, challenging gameplay with high replayability

Cons:

-Steep learning curve; difficult for newcomers or those unfamiliar with Souls-like games
-Trial-and-error gameplay means frequent deaths until mechanics are mastered
-Some early stages might be hard to understand for beginners

Summary:
Hades is a visually stunning and story-rich game that offers a fun and immersive experience, though it can be challenging initially. Definitely worth trying if you enjoy creative storytelling and don’t mind a tough, trial-and-error gameplay style.

Its everything you can ask of a game. Engaging story, sensational soundtrack/music, so fun to play and so many unique playstyles (weapons and builds, all interesting to explore and master). This game is so beautifully balanced in every aspect. This is a gem you need to experience in your life.

Overall grade : 9/10

I purchased this game on sale due to the hype about the release of the second one. It is a roguelike in which you play as the son of the god of the dead trying to escape his father's realm facing hordes of enemies and collecting "boon" power-ups from the gods of Olympus to become more powerful. 

PROS: 
- Progression: The game has an amazing progression system that makes it so every run you unlock something new. It might be small or big but it still helps overall. Every run I would go a bit further and became a bit stronger. Even after you beat the game once you get a new "endless" progression system where you can get more rewards by making the run harder. 
- Dialogue and NPCs: The game feels like it has endless dialogue with it's array of fun and plentiful characters. They will either say the next line that's queued up or, more likely, comment on something you have done. Even in the hub there was always someone to talk to and some quest to progress. For a game like this where you essentially do the same thing over and over this was great to see. 
- Quests and Collectables: During my runs I always made it a priority to do the quests or collect resources that helped me upgrade my hub. It kept me busy and entertained, no need to say more. 
- Boons and Weapons: The boon powers you get from the gods are all fun and different, and you have a tone of ways to combine them and even together with the many weapons to create very powerful and fun builds. You can also use some items and talents to affect these boons so there are many layers of options. That being said, I didn't enjoy using all of the weapons but opinions online vary. 

CONS: 
- Lack of level and enemy variety: The game focuses on quality over quantity. And it is filled to the brim with content for sure. However if you will excuse the spoiler, the game has only a few levels and just as many bosses. Sure all of them (except for 1 very boring boss) change depending on your actions and progression, but compared to other roguelikes that have several times that number of levels it can feel a bit predictable after 10-20 runs. The mobs are also mostly the same every playthrough so you will focus on beating them as fast as possible to get to the next reward and dopamine hit. 
- Strong presence of "woke" political ideals: The game features the ancient Greek pantheon and mythology. And yet many of the characters are featured having skin shades a lot darker than they should be. There are also many LQBT themes and characters. The game also beats you over the head with the importance of consent, even for some very trivial things.  That being said it's not as bad as some other games, which is reflected in it's overwhelmingly positive grade, but I know there are those among you who don't tolerate any of this so I felt it needed to be pointed out. 

Overall I recommend this game, it gave me about 100 hours of fun, quick action and it's worth the price tag. Even better, it's often on sale.

its okay. really overhyped. i really like the dialogue stuff because its quite high effort and unique, i am really into greek lore, i love how the hubs design improves, but the gameplay is just not really all that great. even though there is always new dialogue, it gets quite stale, e.g. talking to hypnos and relatively quickly in i just dont feel like listening / reading through it all. even the reward of getting to mother doesnt really satisfy me after like the fifth time getting. i really dont like purely weapon based gameplay (e.g. hades / dead cells) as opposed to "ability" based gameplay (e.g. wizard of legend, astral ascent) or weapon kits where i have >4 options (e.g. enter the gungeon, binding of isaac), so for me weapons that arent my favourite get very stale quickly in hades specifically. on the topic of weapons, i havent unlocked aspects or other heat related stuff yet, but already really dislike half the weapons and enjoy the other half, meh... in dead cells i enjoy the vast majority of the huge arsenal of weapons and tools, not here sadly. the boons are mostly cool with few exceptions, e.g. ares stacking seems to really suck, athena, zeus, aphro and demeter on the other hand seem crazy broken at times, poseidon is a meme through and through, i SHOULD really love what he does as it encoroporates things i enjoy in games, but i fucking hate using his boons altogether.. they seem great on the surface until you realize how few there really are, it just doesnt feel as unique as playing dead cells or gungeon. and most things are just slight modifiers to how you play anyway, same as many items in gungeon, but at least many guns force different playstyles, e.g. when reloading.

i also really dislike a lot of enemy design, gonna be honest on that one.
e.g. the bone hydra boss when most of em are spamming summons and or fireballs, certain hades summons, anything related to wagons. theseus in his entirety, that fight fucking blows, and most importantly: anything related to butterflies - god the miniboss is so atrociously awful to fight and makes me actually miserable!
this is a huge reason for me not actually continuing, other games like gungeon or wizard of legend have similar challenging or at times annoying enemies, but theyre usually fun or optional to fight. i just cannot ignore how unfun it is fighting chariots and butterflies, elysium in general is a horrendous area and i dread going there every single run..

lookwise i got used to the game and it is quite gorgeous, at least that part of my prejudgemental attitude towards hades did change within my gameplay hours.

overall, i just do not find the combat satisfying or fun enough to wanna continue. unlocks are fun, dialogue etc. is fun, but i dont really care for these nearly enough. the run length is also fine and heat modifiers seem okay enough.

my favourite part was upgrading the lobby and unlocking cool new rooms mid run

I rarely write reviews, but Hades absolutely deserves the additional praise. I'm sure it has been said a thousand times already, but if you are here because you checked a box for action roguelike or roguelite you should absolutely check this title out, and if not you should check it out even sooner. There are few games that deliver on that concept as handily as Supergiant's Hades. If you've never played this style of game you're in for a treat. I would 100% recommend this as an entry point into the genre, I envy your opportunity to start here. This belongs in a hall of fame with other champions such as TBOI. If this franchise is not already on every list of the top 10 games in this category I would be shocked. Well done.

Review:
Elegant simplicity of initial game play meets exceptional attention to detail in every aspect and subtle satisfying growth in complexity as the game progresses. 
This game nails every element that keeps you coming back again and again in a great roguelite. 5 years after release and it still stands out. I am confident I will still be revisiting this game for years to come. 
Hades 2 looks just as brilliant and receives glowing reviews as well. That game caught my eye first, and I am extremely happy with my decision to play this one before starting the next installment. It was absolutely worth visiting first, and the main complaint seems to be that Hades 2 did not break the mold cast by Hades enough. I can't wait to check it out, more of the same with a few new tricks and some additional polish based on player feedback sounds perfect to me!
The storytelling is clever, often relying on, but rarely (if ever) suffering from,character exposition. The tale of Prince Zagreus attempting to leave the nest and the story of his motivations comes across in cleverly executed triggered events which mostly take the form of bite-sized often humorous banter between characters. The blending of a few reenactments and witty dialogue in the retelling of what brought the protagonist to his current state really shines. Hades may not hold the number one spot for depth of story in my library, but it hits it out of the park on lore and theme. This game absolutely delivers a solid and engaging story in a clever way. Honestly the polished, exciting, and dynamic game play alone would shine enough to have hidden a lot of sins, but this game has nothing to hide.   10/10 


Note: I'm not an all-in completionist by nature. I usually play games intensely for a moderate duration until something else captures my attention and I move on to the next exciting thing. That said, I am confident that I will be 100%-ing hades at least once, likely again at the 10 year anniversary.

TLDR: Buy this game... You'll wish you had bought it yesterday and downloaded it already... You're welcome.

What I Loved:

---World & Atmosphere
The game’s setting is astonishing. The landscapes—be it the misty isles of Skellige, the grim streets of Novigrad or the war-torn Northern Kingdoms—feel alive, layered and often haunting. The small environmental touches (weather changes, ambient NPC chatter, background threats) make it more immersive than many open worlds. 

---Storytelling & Characters
The main thread and the side quests alike carry weight. You’ll meet characters you care about, face decisions whose consequences ripple—often unpredictably. The writing is solid, mature (though not flawless) and frequently rewards patience. For example: “monsters you are contracted to slay are deeply connected to the lives of the people who hire you.” 

---Quest Quality (Mostly)
Many side quests aren’t just filler—they tell their own tales, develop the world, introduce moral complexity. For RPG-fans who love exploration and story, that’s a big plus. 

---Scale & Value
There’s so much to do. If you’re willing to dive deep, you’ll get dozens of hours of content, and likely feel the game more than “played.” The scope here is impressive.

---If I were to sum it up: The Witcher 3 is exceptional, but not perfect.
For story- and exploration-loving gamers: strongly recommended. You’ll find a world, characters, and quests that stay with you.

For gamers who prioritize tight, mechanical combat, minimal filler, or super-streamlined systems: you might get frustrated with some of the rough edges.

I’d give it something like 4.5/5 (or 9/10) in many cases—meaning: one of the best games of its generation, with meaningful caveats.

My all-time favorite: Witcher 3. The atmosphere, the story, the characters, the quests — everything is crafted beautifully. It all comes together in a way that keeps you hooked without even trying. You start doing one side quest, and next thing you know, you’re knee-deep in three more without even realizing it. It’s like being caught in a current; the game flows so naturally, you just drift from one quest to the next. That’s how immersive it is. Now I’m just waiting for Witcher 4 to drop — hoping it’ll pull me in just as deep.

You’re a dad, a detective, a part-time sorceress magnet, and a full-time professional sigh-er. One minute you’re slaying demons, the next you’re collecting herbs like an unemployed botanist. 10/10—would once again ruin my life chasing Gwent cards while pretending to care about the fate of the world.

The game is phenomenal, in your search to build up your Gwent card deck it takes you across some beautiful landscapes, and the power you feel coming to blows with an opponent and utilising your cards to the best of their advantage, and wiping the floor with an opponent in the search for more and more legendary cards to build the strongest decks you can is insurmountable. On top of this the choices are not always blatantly obvious, in some cases the lines are blurred, sometimes you may place down a card you should have saved for later, or may even pass your go when you should have placed more down. 


The side content, such as looking for Ciri and battling the Wild Hunt are OK too, I guess.

Simply The Best RPG Game Ever Made, The Witcher 3 is an amazing, Story Interesting and Rich-Atmosphere 
Product!

The game isn't easy nor is it bs. It feels like a nice middle ground, where you can't be asleep at the wheel, nor have to try super hard. Enemies can kill you quickly, but can be easily dodged and chipped down. Healing is mostly done thru eating food and killing enemies in battle, but you can also make potions that will heal you but toxify your system. Enemy variety is really good. While there are recurring enemy types like wild dogs, wolves, ghouls and drowners, there are rarer enemies that take a lot more effort to kill. I bet I haven't seen even half them. Stronger enemies usually act as boss fights, where you're in an isolated arena and aren't outnumbered (usually). Humans are also enemies. Side quests are really good, whereas in Elder Scrolls there are only a few good ones in IV and V. Randomly stumbling upon a quest marker and it turning into a side quest about a small village all being turned into pigs blew me away.

The decision making in the dialogue/quests in the witcher 3 are generally a lot better than in games from bioware, ubisoft and telltale games; i usually feel like in those games every decision i make has some sort of negative outcome or makes another character hate me for seemingly no reason. In the witcher 3 you can pretty much do what you feel is right for your own reasoning, with no clear right or wrong decision, and chances are Geralt will reciprocate that himself in his dialogue; Geralt is a fantastic character for an RPG, as while hes still kind of a "blank slate" for the player, he still has morals and a personality, meaning that the choices you make in the game are all things that you can definitely see him choosing himself, "good" or "bad". this was honestly a huge breath of fresh air for me after being constantly told how stupid i am after every choice in the aforementioned "RPG"s. 
Sadly i will say that the only time where the whole "consequences of your actions" fall apart in this game is quite literally in the most integral parts of the plot, especially in regards to the different endings of the main story and the Blood and Wine DLC, but ill let it off i suppose

The Witcher 3 isn’t just a game, it’s an experience. Everything from the story to the characters, the world, the writing it’s all incredible. But before you play it, I highly recommend playing Witcher 2 first. You’ll meet many characters in Witcher 3 who were already part of Witcher 2, and knowing their stories makes your whole experience so much better.

Play it on Death March or at least Blood and Broken Bones difficulty. Playing on easier difficulty makes potions and oils feel kind of useless, and that’s a big part of what makes being a Witcher so cool.

Do as many side quests as you can, seriously, some of them are more memorable, more emotional, and better written than entire main stories in other games.

Don’t get me started on the music.. just experience it yourself

The DLCs are absolute perfection they’re not just add ons, they’re full blown masterpieces that could easily be standalone games.

For me, this game is an easy ∞/10. Absolute masterpiece, everyone should play it at least once. I’ll definitely be playing it again before Witcher 4 releases.

The Witcher 3, since it came out in 2015, I've heard it mentioned as one of the best games of all time. It's always in the top 5 of any list of favorite video games.

I've always known what the game was about, but it never intrigued me because I grew up playing Skyrim, Dragon Age, and recently Baldur's Gate, etc.

So I've always had a repulsion for these medieval fantasy worlds. In fact, I started The Witcher 3 by doing the first quests, but I was incredibly bored. I remember putting off the first quest after the prologue for months.

So, at a certain point, I forced myself to continue playing the game. Slowly, I managed to make my way through the story, continuing to only do the primary quests. Before finding Ciri, for me, the game was something I had to do because I wanted to understand what was so special about it. After finding Ciri, the game changed. Totally amazing storytelling and story, from there I started playing it for days until I finished the main story.

I have to say that only after finishing the game can I say that it is OBJECTIVELY one of the best ever made. It's like an ancestor of RDR2, a fantasy version. Everything in the game is content, nothing is secondary, nothing is useless, all the quests and all the interactions are written to be enjoyable. I could spend hours listing the game's strengths, but I want to focus on something that really struck me.

I don't know why, but CD Red has churned out incredible DLC for both The Witcher and Cyberpunk. There are DLCs that are as good as the game itself, if not more.

Hearth of Stone is an incredible DLC, and I loved it for the strange sequence of events that then leads you into the story, but above all for the crazy difficulty of the boss fights. Up until that point, the game was so easy, but the Hearth of Stone bosses literally made me sweat. I was there, struggling, and it was obvious they did it on purpose. It's really fun. Blood and Wine, on the other hand, is a masterpiece. I think it captures everything about the game and translates it into additional content. This DLC contains my favorite part of the game, and perhaps one of my all-time favorites: the fairy tale quest. I think I took 200 screenshots just of the landscape of the DLC area.

In conclusion,
the game is objectively one of the best I've ever played. Anyone who considers themselves a gamer should play and finish it. Perhaps it's truly a work of art. I can't wait for the 4th.

[158시간 도전과제 100% 올클리어]

[h1] THE WITCHER [/h1]
플스로 아주 오래전에 엔딩을 보고 PC판으로 정말 오랜만에 다시 플레이했습니다. 어마어마한 플레이 타임을 알기에 선뜻 시작하긴 어려웠지만 역시는 역시네요. 위쳐3는 숫자3이 붙어 있는게 거슬릴 정도로 그냥 THE Wicther 자체가 되어야 맞지 않을까..하는 생각이 들었습니다. 장점만 있는 게임은 아닙니다, 하지만 장점이 너무 많달까. 

이미 엔딩을 본 게임이기에 한 번에 도과 100%를 하려고 처음부터 최고 난이도인 [죽음의 행진] 난이도로 진행했습니다. 실패한 2개 퀘스트 제외하고 모든 사이드 퀘스트를 다 했고, 지도에 있는 대부분 물음표 마크는 대부분 공략했습니다 (스켈리가는 아직도 몇 개 남았는데 이건 좀..) 

[서사와 선택으로 생동감을 불어넣은 중세 판타지 월드]
작가들이 열일했다.. 라는 생각이 듭니다. 사실 맵 크기로 보면 어쎄신 크리드 시리즈도 어디가서 꿀리지 않습니다. 그런데 두 시리즈에서 느끼는 생동감의 차이는 대체 뭘까요. 바로 캐릭터들의 [서사]라고 할 수 있습니다. 사이드 퀘스트에도 상당한 분량을 할애해서 수많은 사이드 퀘스트에 흥미로운 이야기를 집어 넣었습니다. 거기에 유저들에게 일정 [선택]을 부여했구요. 예를 들어, 길가다가 만난 사이드 퀘스트인데 숫가락을 모으는 저주 받은 괴물을 만나 그냥 죽일 수도 있고 상당히 번거로운 길을 돌아 저주를 풀어줄 수도 있습니다. 훗날 이 괴물은 저주가 풀려 위쳐 집에서 요리사로 일하게 됩니다. 이 정도 분량을 가진 퀘스트라면 다른 게임에서 어떻게든 메인 스트리와 연계해서 보여주려고 노력할텐데 위쳐3에서는 그냥 길 가다가 만난 사이드 퀘스트 중의 하나입니다. 그렇기 떄문에 더 세계를 탐험하고 싶다는 욕구를 들게 만드는거구요. 돌아다니다보면 어떤 흥미로운 일을 만날지 모르니까요. 

이 [선택]은 메인 퀘스트에도 빛이 납니다. 다양한 분기점을 집어 넣어서 유저의 선택에 따라 각기 다른 엔딩과 컷신을 볼 수 있어 게임을 클리어하고 나서도 다시 플레이하게 만드는 동기가 충분했습니다.  

[위쳐는 바람둥이야 H씬] 
애들은 가라! 예니퍼라는 정실?이 있음에도 게롤트는 다양한 인물들과 사랑을 나눌 수 있습니다. H씬이 정말 야한 것도 아닌데 뭔가 유저들을 집중하게 만드는 매력이 있달까. 딱 그 선을 잘 지킨 것 같슴다. 다다익선(?)이라고 최대한 많은 씬을 보면서 흐믓해하고 있는 자신을 보고 있자면 이 게임의 매력의 하나인건 분명하네요. 개인적으로 예니퍼는 너무 까칠하고 되려 트리스 성격이 마음에 들었는데 캐릭터 모델링도 그렇고 메인 스토리 따라가다보니 예니퍼로 돌아섰네요 ㅠ (여기엔 유니콘이 컸다..)  

세상 모든 게임에는 장단점이 있습니다. 위쳐와 같은 게임을 안 좋아할만한 분들도 분명히 있다고 생각해요. 

[상대적으로 어색한 모션]
확실히 연식이 있는 게임이라고 느끼는게 최근 나온 게임들과 비교하면 움직임이 아주 매끄럽지가 않습니다. 뭐 몰입을 방해할 정도는 아니고 익숙해지면 또 괜찮습니다만. 특정 벽이나 구간에서 끼어서 움직이지 못하는 경우가 가끔 있다는 거. 

[텍스트의 홍수]
위쳐3는 기본적으로 서사(이야기)를 통해서 유저의 흥미를 이끌어내는 방식을 취하기 때문에 주어지는 텍스트의 양이 정말 어마어마합니다. 스토리텔링을 좋아하는 유저 입장에서는 너무 좋지만, 텍스트를 읽어가며 시간을 들여서 스토리 흐름을 따라가야 하기 때문에 머리 비우고 액션만 즐기고 싶은 유저에게는 게임 자체를 스킵해버리고 싶을 수도 있습니다.  한 마디로 인스턴트 라면 먹고 싶은 사람에게 진하디 진한 꼬리곰탕을 내밀면서 먹으라는 느낌이겠네요. 저는 개인적으로 극호였습니다만.. 

장단점 외에 다른 이야기를 조금 해보자면.. 

[진정한 위쳐라면 죽행] 
만약 본인이 조금 매콤하게 진행하고 싶다? 최고 난이도인 죽음의 행진으로 플레이하는 걸 강력하게 추천드립니다. 위쳐는 기본적인 검술 외에도 표식과 물약을 쓸 수 있는데 쉬운 난이도에서는 그냥 검만 쓰고 표식은 곁다리로, 물약은 딱히 신경 안 써도 다 깰 수 있습니다. 너무 쉽달까. 하지만 죽행 난이도는 적들이 죽창(?)을 들고 다니기 때문에 쓸 수 있는 거 싸그리 다 써야 합니다. 검술, 표식, 물약을 다 갖춘 진정한(?) 위쳐로 거듭날 수 있습니다 ㅎㅎ 매번 괴물 도감을 잘 살펴보며 효과있는 기름도 꼼꼼히 발라야 생존할 수 있습니다 ㅎㅎ 특히 초반에 엄청 매운데, 중후반 가면서 난이도가 점점 낮아지는 편입니다. 

[다양한 스타일로 플레이 해보자] 
위쳐에는 늑대, 곰, 살쾡이, 바이퍼, 맨티코어 등 다양한 교단이 존재합니다. 위쳐 장비가 아닌 장비들도 착용 가능하지만, 성능과 룩에서 너무나 큰 차이를 보이기 때문에 컨셉 플레이가 아닌 이상 글쎄요. 윗 등급으로 갈수록 장비를 만드는데 엄청난 노력과 돈이 들어가기 때문에 본인 선호하는 스타일과 세트 보너스에 맞춰 1-2개 정해놓고 고것만 쭉쭉 업그레이드하시는게 정신 건강에 좋습니다. 저는 다 만들려고 했다가 돈이 너무 급격하게 빨려서 포기했습니다. 저는 넷플릭스 위쳐에서 헨리 카빌이 입는 잊혀진 늑대 교단과 곰 교단이 가장 멋지달까. 

오랜만에 너무 너무 재밌게 플레이했고 도과를 다 하고 나서도 도과랑 관련 없는 퀘스트도 다 해버린 유일무이한 게임이 아닐까 싶네요 (보통 도과랑 관련 없으면 무시하는게 다반사인데..) 

위쳐3하고 나니 사이버펑크 2077도 해보고 싶다는 생각이 불쑥 듭니다. 1인칭 뷰는 좀 별로라 안 했거든요. 위쳐 4 개발에 들어갔으니 그 동안 다른 걸로 시간이라도 떄워봐야지 ㅠ

94/100 A really good RPG.  

Not quite as good as Zelda Breath of the Wild, but a hugely in-depth game with a massive open world chock full of interesting content and quests, cool lore and monsters, and rich progression systems.  

There is some stuff that sucks, like horse riding and horse races, fist fights, the boss fight with Detlaff, playing as Ciri is no fun because she is so weak, the sound regularly not working when the game starts, no controller key for quicksave (long pressing the view button would have worked), and the annoying unnecessary launcher.  

This is definitely a game you should play, but be warned it is a big game. 

If you're playing for the first time then here are some controller shortcuts which are not obvious: long pressing the controller menu button takes you straight into world map, pressing left stick (no need to hold) puts you into run/swim fast mode including when indoors, pressing right stick changes/cycles the active objective when you have a quest active that has multiple simultaneous objectives.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a masterpiece that sets the bar for open-world RPGs. Its gripping story, rich world-building, and complex characters make every moment unforgettable. The expansions elevate it further: Hearts of Stone is a standout with its tight narrative and morally gray choices, perfectly capturing the game’s dark, gritty essence. Blood and Wine offers a vibrant, expansive region with some truly memorable quests, though a few lean a bit cheesy, slightly diverging from the main game’s tone. Still, the overall experience is flawless—CD Projekt Red nailed it. 10/10, a must-play on Steam.
A great masterpiece of the 21st century — no explanation needed.

After 200 hours i can confidently say that the Witcher 3 is one of best Open World games of all time and has its GOTY reputation well earned, the quests are masterfully crafted keeping you entertained and wishing for more. If you haven't played it yet, i truly recommend to try it at least once in your life and of course try out the mods. 10/10

Immersive experience with the characters, every decision you make will make sense even affect the world scenario, leading to rises and falls of kingdoms. Even if one uninterested in big picture, romantic relations with Triss or Yennefer still touched me a lot. Don't start playing Gwent cards or you will miss the point! (LOL)
